\name: Lightweight Non-Parametric
Fine-Tuning of Embeddings for Retrieval

Sepanta Zeighami
UC Berkeley
zeighami@berkeley.edu
&Zac Wellmer
zac@1984.ai &Aditya Parameswaran
UC Berkeley
adityagp@berkeley.edu
Abstract

kğ‘˜kitalic_k-Nearest Neighbor search on dense vector embeddings (kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval) from pre-trained embedding models is the predominant retrieval method for text and images, as well as Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pipelines. In practice, application developers often fine-tune the embeddings to improve their accuracy on the dataset and query workload in hand. Existing approaches either fine-tune the pre-trained model itself or, more efficiently, but at the cost of accuracy, train adaptor models to transform the output of the pre-trained model. We present \name, a family of novel non-parametric embedding fine-tuning approaches that are significantly more accurate and efficient than both sets of existing approaches. \name directly modifies the embeddings of data records to maximize the accuracy of kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval. We present a thorough theoretical and experimental study of \nameâ€™s non-parametric approach. We show that even though the underlying problem is NP-Hard, constrained variations can be solved efficiently. These constraints additionally ensure that the changes to the embeddings are modest, avoiding large distortions to the semantics learned during pre-training. In experiments across five pre-trained models and nine standard text and image retrieval datasets, \name runs in minutes and often improves NDCG@10 by more than 10% over existing fine-tuning methods. On average, \name provides 3.3Ã—\timesÃ— and 4.3Ã—\timesÃ— higher increase in accuracy and runs 200Ã—\timesÃ— and 3Ã—\timesÃ— faster, respectively, over fine-tuning the pre-trained model and training adaptors. 111Code available at https://github.com/szeighami/nudge.

1 Introduction

kğ‘˜kitalic_k-Nearest Neighbor search on dense vector embeddings (kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval) from pre-trained embedding models is the de-facto standard for text and image retrieval, as well as in Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pipelines. (Lewis etÂ al., 2020; Li etÂ al., 2023a; Gao etÂ al., 2023; Patil etÂ al., 2023; Du etÂ al., 2022; Liu etÂ al., 2021b). Given nğ‘›nitalic_n data records (e.g., text chunks or images), kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval embeds them using a pre-trained model as dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional vectors in â„›dsuperscriptâ„›ğ‘‘\mathcal{R}^{d}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To answer a query, it similarly embeds the query in â„›dsuperscriptâ„›ğ‘‘\mathcal{R}^{d}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and retrieves the top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k data records whose embeddings have the highest cosine similarity (or inner product) with the query embedding. By simply performing a top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k look-up (often through vector databases), the simplicity and efficiency of kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval has made it increasingly popular and often preferred to other retrieval paradigms, e.g., late interaction (Khattab & Zaharia, 2020; Santhanam etÂ al., 2021) or generative retrieval (Tay etÂ al., 2022; Wang etÂ al., 2022). However, the out-of-the-box pre-trained model is often not sufficiently accurate on the dataset or queries in hand, and typically fine-tuning is used to improve the accuracy.

There are two standard approaches to fine-tuning embeddings: fine-tuning the pre-trained models directly (referred to henceforth as PTFT) or training adaptor models on top of the pre-trained models (Zhao etÂ al., 2024; Zhou etÂ al., 2024; Aarsen, 2024; SuvanshÂ Sanjeev, 2024; LlamaIndex, 2024b). PTFT can be more accurate but comes with practical challenges: it (1) requires access to the model parameters and must rely on third-party APIs for closed-source models 222E.g., OpenAI currently does not provide an interface for fine-tuning embedding model (OpenAI, 2024b)., (2) is computationally expensive, and (3) incurs further hosting and maintenance costs for deployment of the fine-tuned model. An alternative is to learn an Adaptor, g^Î¸subscript^ğ‘”ğœƒ\hat{g}_{\theta}over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, a transformation of the output of the (frozen) pre-trained model, f^^ğ‘“\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG, so that the function g^Î¸âˆ˜f^subscript^ğ‘”ğœƒ^ğ‘“\hat{g}_{\theta}\circ\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ˜ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG generates accurate data and/or query embeddings. Training g^Î¸subscript^ğ‘”ğœƒ\hat{g}_{\theta}over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be done model-agnostically, that is, with only black-box access to the pre-trained model, addressing (1). Moreover, Adaptors are typically small models, such as linear models (LlamaIndex, 2024b), addressing (2), and lowering the associated costs in (3). Nonetheless, experimental results show, at best, modest accuracy gains from using Adaptors. We, therefore, lack a fine-tuning approach for kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval that is simultaneously effective, efficient, and easy-to-use.

We present \name, a family of approaches to non-parametrically fine-tune embeddings efficiently. \name methods (or \names) are surprisingly effective, model-agnostic, and incur no additional deployment cost. \names take a novel non-parametric view of embedding fine-tuning: they view the embeddings themselves as parameters of the kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval algorithm and directly modify the embeddings of data records to maximize the accuracy of kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval. Although we show that the underlying optimization problem is NP-Hard in general, and can lead to overfitting if data embeddings are allowed to change arbitrarily, \names efficiently solve constrained variations of this problem formulated to avoid overfitting. As shown in Fig.Â 1, \names change each data embedding to maximize the similarity between the data embedding and the training queries to which the data record is a correct answer, while constraining how and by how much the embedding can change. Intuitively, the constraints allow for enough modifications to the embeddings to improve accuracy on the dataset in hand while avoiding large distortion that would offset the semantics learned during pre-training. Fig.Â 1 shows an example of the constrained region used, where new embeddings are constrained to be normalized (i.e., to fall on the unit ball), and the magnitude of changes to the embeddings to be bounded. \names solve the constrained optimization problems in closed form, presenting simple and effective update formulae for embedding fine-tuning.

\name

â€™s non-parametric formulation contrasts with the parametric approaches adopted by PTFT and Adaptors that increase the similarity between query and answer pairs through contrastive-type losses (Zhao etÂ al., 2024). Through constrained non-parametric optimization, \names instead make bounded local changes to each individual data embedding. On the other hand, PTFT and Adaptors make potentially large global changes to the embedding function that modify the embeddings of all possible data and queries. However, learning modifications that generalize across all data and queries is difficult from the typically small training sets available during fine-tuning. Instead, models end up overfitting to the training set. Besides accuracy gains, the non-parametric formulation allows for efficient closed-form solutions to the optimization problem. \names use computation equivalent (up to a log factor) to a single training and validation iteration of Adaptors.

We present a thorough experimental evaluation, showing that \names significantly outperform Adaptors and PTFT on standard text retrieval datasets from BEIR (Thakur etÂ al., 2021) and KILT (Petroni etÂ al., 2021) and image retrieval datasets COCOÂ (Lin etÂ al., 2014) and FlickrÂ (Young etÂ al., 2014). \names improve common metrics such as Recall@10101010 and NDCG@10101010 by up to 16.0% more than both PTFT and Adaptors and 24.4% over no fine-tuning. Across 9 different datasets and 5 different embedding models \names consistently outperform PTFT and Adaptors, often providing 10% more increase in NDGC@10. \names avoid performance degradation on out-of-distribution queries that affect parametric approaches, ensuring that the significant accuracy gains for in-distribution queries do not come at the expense of out-of-distribution queries. Moreover, \names are model-agnostic and can be used with any (potentially closed-source) embedding model. Overall, \names are trained in minutes on datasets with millions of records, and the fine-tuned embeddings can be used directly without any additional model inference cost, providing significant accuracy boosts almost â€œfor freeâ€.

Contributions and Overview. To summarize, our contributions are as follows.

  • â€¢

    We formalize the notion of non-parametric embedding fine-tuning and show that the underlying unconstrained non-parametric optimization problem is NP-Hard (Sec.Â 3.1).

  • â€¢

    We present \name-M and \name-N, two methods that optimally solve constrained variations of the problem (Sec.Â 3.2). \name-M updates data embeddings to maximize the similarity between the embeddings of queries and their ground-truth data records subject to a bound on the magnitude of change to the embeddings. \name-N adopts a similar approach, but additionally constrains the embeddings to be normalized.

  • â€¢

    We show \name variants consistently outperform parametric fine-tuning methods with thorough experiments on 5 embedding models and 9 standard retrieval datasets (Sec.Â 4).

2 Preliminaries

Notation. We use bar Â¯Â¯absent\bar{}overÂ¯ start_ARG end_ARG on top of letters to denote raw data/queries that are not embedded. We use boldface capital letters to denote matrices (mostly used to represent embeddings), e.g., ğ‘¿âˆˆâ„›rÃ—sğ‘¿superscriptâ„›ğ‘Ÿğ‘ {\bm{X}}\in\mathcal{R}^{r\times s}bold_italic_X âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r Ã— italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an rÃ—sğ‘Ÿğ‘ r\times sitalic_r Ã— italic_s matrix, and use ğ‘¿isubscriptğ‘¿ğ‘–{\bm{X}}_{i}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to refer to the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th row of the matrix, which is a vector, ğ‘¿iâˆˆâ„›ssubscriptğ‘¿ğ‘–superscriptâ„›ğ‘ {\bm{X}}_{i}\in\mathcal{R}^{s}bold_italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. â€–ğ’™â€–normğ’™\|{\bm{x}}\|âˆ¥ bold_italic_x âˆ¥ refers to the L2 norm of a vector ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}}bold_italic_x, and â€–ğ‘¿â€–normğ‘¿\|{\bm{X}}\|âˆ¥ bold_italic_X âˆ¥ refers to the vector of row-wise norms, (â€–ğ‘¿1â€–,â€¦,â€–ğ‘¿râ€–)normsubscriptğ‘¿1â€¦normsubscriptğ‘¿ğ‘Ÿ(\|{\bm{X}}_{1}\|,...,\|{\bm{X}}_{r}\|)( âˆ¥ bold_italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ , â€¦ , âˆ¥ bold_italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ ). We use [s]delimited-[]ğ‘ [s][ italic_s ] to refer to the set {1,2,â€¦,s}12â€¦ğ‘ \{1,2,...,s\}{ 1 , 2 , â€¦ , italic_s }.

kğ‘˜kitalic_k-Nearest Neighbor Retrieval. Given a dataset, DÂ¯Â¯ğ·\bar{D}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_D end_ARG of nğ‘›nitalic_n records (e.g., text chunks or images), kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval first embeds the data records using an embedding model, â„°Dsubscriptâ„°ğ·\mathcal{E}_{D}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, to generate an embedding matrix ğ‘«âˆˆâ„›nÃ—dğ‘«superscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ‘‘{\bm{D}}\in\mathcal{R}^{n\times d}bold_italic_D âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where dğ‘‘ditalic_d is the embedding dimensionality. The iğ‘–iitalic_i-th row, ğ‘«isubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–{\bm{D}}_{i}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, of ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}}bold_italic_D is the embedding of the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th record, DÂ¯isubscriptÂ¯ğ·ğ‘–\bar{D}_{i}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, that is, ğ‘«i=â„°Dâ¢(DÂ¯i)subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptâ„°ğ·subscriptÂ¯ğ·ğ‘–{\bm{D}}_{i}=\mathcal{E}_{D}(\bar{D}_{i})bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). To answer a query qÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\bar{q}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG, kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval first embeds the query using an embedding model, â„°Qsubscriptâ„°ğ‘„\mathcal{E}_{Q}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (often â„°Qsubscriptâ„°ğ‘„\mathcal{E}_{Q}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â„°Dsubscriptâ„°ğ·\mathcal{E}_{D}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the same, but can be different, especially in a multi-modal setting) to obtain ğ’’=â„°Qâ¢(qÂ¯)ğ’’subscriptâ„°ğ‘„Â¯ğ‘{\bm{q}}=\mathcal{E}_{Q}(\bar{q})bold_italic_q = caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG ). kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval then returns the top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k records in DÂ¯Â¯ğ·\bar{D}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_D end_ARG whose embeddings have the highest similarity to ğ’’ğ’’{\bm{q}}bold_italic_q, measured by either the inner product or cosine similarity, i.e., the kğ‘˜kitalic_k records DÂ¯i1,â€¦,DÂ¯iksubscriptÂ¯ğ·subscriptğ‘–1â€¦subscriptÂ¯ğ·subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜\bar{D}_{{i}_{1}},...,\bar{D}_{{i}_{k}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that correspond to the kğ‘˜kitalic_k highest values in the set {ğ‘«1â‹…ğ’’,â€¦,ğ‘«nâ‹…ğ’’}â‹…subscriptğ‘«1ğ’’â€¦â‹…subscriptğ‘«ğ‘›ğ’’\{{\bm{D}}_{1}\cdot{\bm{q}},...,{\bm{D}}_{n}\cdot{\bm{q}}\}{ bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_q , â€¦ , bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_q } when using the inner product similarity metric. By default, we use the inner product, which can be applied to normalized embeddings to obtain cosine similarity.

Ground-Truth Answers. Queries can require retrieving multiple data records, and each data record can have a different degree of relevance to the query. For simplicity, here, we present our results in the setting where a query, qÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\bar{q}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG, requires retrieving a single ground-truth data record. We refer to the ground-truth data record for a query, qÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\bar{q}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG, as the ground-truth answer to the query and often refer to the data record with its index yğ‘¦yitalic_y, yâˆˆ[n]ğ‘¦delimited-[]ğ‘›y\in[n]italic_y âˆˆ [ italic_n ]. Extensions to multiple ground-truth data records (each with potentially different degrees of relevance to the query) is straightforward and presented in Appx.Â D.

Fine-Tuning. Fine-tuning aims to improve retrieval accuracy for the dataset DÂ¯Â¯ğ·\bar{D}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_D end_ARG through optimizing embeddings. We let ğ‘«âˆ—âˆˆâ„›nÃ—dsuperscriptğ‘«superscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ‘‘{\bm{D}}^{*}\in\mathcal{R}^{n\times d}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the fine-tuned data embeddings obtained after fine-tuning, where ğ‘«iâˆ—âˆˆâ„›dsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘«ğ‘–superscriptâ„›ğ‘‘{\bm{D}}^{*}_{i}\in\mathcal{R}^{d}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the fine-tuned embedding for the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th data record. We consider a supervised setting where a query set with corresponding ground-truth answers is available, consisting of the query set, QÂ¯Â¯ğ‘„\bar{Q}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG, and a set, Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y, of ground-truth answers, where Yjsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘—Y_{j}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the index of the ground-truth answer for the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th query, qÂ¯jsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘—\bar{q}_{j}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We split this set into two, a training set QÂ¯T,YTsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘„ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡\bar{Q}^{T},Y^{T}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and a validation set QÂ¯V,YVsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘„ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘Œğ‘‰\bar{Q}^{V},Y^{V}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with nTsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡n_{T}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and nVsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰n_{V}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT queries, respectively. Let ğ‘¸Tâˆˆâ„›nTÃ—dsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘‡superscriptâ„›subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡ğ‘‘{\bm{Q}}^{T}\in\mathcal{R}^{n_{T}\times d}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ‘¸Vâˆˆâ„›nVÃ—dsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘‰superscriptâ„›subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰ğ‘‘{\bm{Q}}^{V}\in\mathcal{R}^{n_{V}\times d}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be matrices containing embeddings for training and validation queries. The training set can be collected over time from user interactions with the system, by collecting labels, or by generating synthetic training data using LLMs (e.g., LlamaIndex (2024a); Meng etÂ al. (2022)).

3 Non-Parametric Embedding Fine-Tuning

Our \name approach views embeddings as parameters of the kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval algorithm, optimizing the embeddings directly to improve retrieval accuracy. In Sec.Â 3.1, we formalize the notion of non-parametric embedding fine-tuning by stating two optimization problems, one directly maximizing a retrieval accuracy metric and one maximizing similarity between queries and their ground-truth answers. Maximizing accuracy is the final goal, but similarity is a simpler surrogate to optimize in practice. Nonetheless, we show that the former is NP-hard and the latter is unbounded (i.e., the objective can be improved indefinitely). Moreover, since both optimization problems allow embeddings to arbitrarily change (i.e., are unconstrained), directly solving either problem can lead to overfitting. In Sec.Â 3.2, we present \name, a family of approaches that solve a combination of constrained variations of the two optimization problems to address generalization and efficiency challenges.

3.1 Unconstrained Non-Parametric Embedding Fine-Tuning Problems

Let ğš«âˆˆâ„›nÃ—dğš«superscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ‘‘{\bm{\Delta}}\in\mathcal{R}^{n\times d}bold_Î” âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the modification to be learned to the embeddings, so that its iğ‘–iitalic_i-th row, ğš«isubscriptğš«ğ‘–{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is the modification to ğ‘«isubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–{\bm{D}}_{i}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. That is, after fine-tuning, the final embedding is ğ‘«âˆ—=ğ‘«+ğš«superscriptğ‘«ğ‘«ğš«{\bm{D}}^{*}={\bm{D}}+{\bm{\Delta}}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_D + bold_Î”. We use ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}}bold_italic_Q and Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y to refer to a generic query embedding matrix with corresponding ground-truth answers containing Nğ‘Nitalic_N queries. ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}}bold_italic_Q and Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y can respectively be either ğ‘¸Tsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘‡{\bm{Q}}^{T}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and YTsuperscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y^{T}italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or ğ‘¸Vsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘‰{\bm{Q}}^{V}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and YVsuperscriptğ‘Œğ‘‰Y^{V}italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

MaxA-EFT. Maximum Accuracy Embedding Fine-Tuning Problem, MaxA-EFT, is the problem of finding ğš«ğš«{\bm{\Delta}}bold_Î” to fine-tune data embeddings that maximizes the number of queries in ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}}bold_italic_Q answered correctly, formalized as follows. For a query embedding matrix ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}}bold_italic_Q with ground-truth answers Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y, let â„iâ¢(ğš«)subscriptâ„ğ‘–ğš«\mathcal{I}_{i}({\bm{\Delta}})caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_Î” ), for iâˆˆ[N]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘i\in[N]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_N ], be the indicator variable denoting if the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th query is answered correctly after fine-tuning with ğš«ğš«{\bm{\Delta}}bold_Î”. Formally, â„iâ¢(ğš«)=1subscriptâ„ğ‘–ğš«1\mathcal{I}_{i}({\bm{\Delta}})=1caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_Î” ) = 1 if the following holds, and zero otherwise

ğ‘¸iâ‹…(ğ‘«Yi+ğš«Yi)>ğ‘¸iâ‹…(ğ‘«j+ğš«j),âˆ€jâˆˆ[n]âˆ–Yi.formulae-sequenceâ‹…subscriptğ‘¸ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–subscriptğš«subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–â‹…subscriptğ‘¸ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘—subscriptğš«ğ‘—for-allğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–\displaystyle{\bm{Q}}_{i}\cdot({\bm{D}}_{Y_{i}}+{\bm{\Delta}}_{Y_{i}})>{\bm{Q}% }_{i}\cdot({\bm{D}}_{j}+{\bm{\Delta}}_{j}),\quad\forall j\in[n]\setminus Y_{i}.bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , âˆ€ italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_n ] âˆ– italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (1)
Problem 1 (MaxA-EFT).

MaxA-EFT is the problem of finding ğš«ğš«{\bm{\Delta}}bold_Î” to maximize the number of queries answered correctly after fine-tuning with ğš«ğš«{\bm{\Delta}}bold_Î”, i.e., argâ¡maxğš«âˆˆâ„›nÃ—dâ¢âˆ‘iâˆˆ[N]â„iâ¢(ğš«).subscriptğš«superscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘–ğš«{\arg\max}_{{\bm{\Delta}}\in\mathcal{R}^{n\times d}}\sum_{i\in[N]}\mathcal{I}_% {i}({\bm{\Delta}}).roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_Î” âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_N ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_Î” ) .

Theorem 1.

MaxA-EFT is NP-Hard.

TheoremÂ 1 is proved by reduction from the Maximum Feasible Linear Subsystem problem as studied in Â Amaldi & Kann (1995), see Appx.Â B.1. Apart from the NP-hardness, MaxA-EFT allows data embeddings to be arbitrarily changed by ğš«ğš«{\bm{\Delta}}bold_Î”. This can distort the semantics captured in ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}}bold_italic_D by the pre-trained model, and lead to poor generalization to queries outside of ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}}bold_italic_Q.

MaxS-EFT. An alternative formulation is Maximum Similarity Embedding Fine-Tuning Problem,

argâ¡maxğš«âˆˆâ„›nÃ—dâ¢âˆ‘iâˆˆ[N]ğ‘¸iâ‹…(ğ‘«Yi+ğš«Yi),ğš«superscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘â‹…subscriptğ‘¸ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–subscriptğš«subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–\displaystyle\underset{{\bm{\Delta}}\in\mathcal{R}^{n\times d}}{\arg\max}\sum_% {i\in[N]}{\bm{Q}}_{i}\cdot({\bm{D}}_{Y_{i}}+{\bm{\Delta}}_{Y_{i}}),start_UNDERACCENT bold_Î” âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_arg roman_max end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_N ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (2)

referred to as MaxS-EFT. Here, we change data embeddings to maximize the similarity between queries and ground-truth answers, a standard optimization objective (e.g., Henderson etÂ al. (2017), SentenceTransformers (2024b)). However, the non-parametric formulation makes Eq.Â 2 an unconstrained optimization problem with a linear objective, so the problem is unbounded and has no optimal solution. Moreover, setting ğš«Yisubscriptğš«subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–{\bm{\Delta}}_{Y_{i}}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT so that ğ‘¸iâ‹…ğš«Yi>0â‹…subscriptğ‘¸ğ‘–subscriptğš«subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–0{\bm{Q}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{\Delta}}_{Y_{i}}>0bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 and increasing the magnitude of ğš«Yisubscriptğš«subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–{\bm{\Delta}}_{Y_{i}}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT arbitrarily improves the objective, yielding trivial solutions with poor generalization to unseen queries.

3.2 \name Approaches

Because of the potential for overfitting and the computational challenges due to NP-hardness, we do not solve either MaxA-EFT or MaxS-EFT directly. Instead, we introduce \name, a family of approaches that solve constrained variations of MaxA-EFT and MaxS-EFT, designed to avoid overfitting, while being efficient. We discuss two main approaches, \name-M and \name-N, in Secs.Â 3.2.1 and 3.2.2 and present other practical extensions in Appx.Â C.

3.2.1 \name-M: \name with Bounded Magnitude

\name

-M solves MaxS-EFT on the training set, but with the added constraint â€–ğš«iâ€–â‰¤Î³normsubscriptğš«ğ‘–ğ›¾\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|\leq\gammaâˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_Î³, âˆ€iâˆˆ[n]for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›\forall i\in[n]âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ], for a scalar Î³â‰¥0ğ›¾0\gamma\geq 0italic_Î³ â‰¥ 0. Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ controls how much each embedding can change during fine-tuning. \name-M sets Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ by solving MaxA-EFT on the validation set. Intuitively, this (1) changes data embeddings to maximize the similarity between embeddings and queries on the training set, (2) ensures that the magnitude of the changes to the embeddings is bounded to avoid overfitting, and (3) decides how much the embeddings are allowed to change by maximizing validation accuracy. \name-M provides a closed-form solution to do this. We provide an overview of the solution here and leave the details and formal proofs to Appx.Â B.2.

Optimization Formulation. Define MaxS-M(Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³), for a scalar Î³â‰¥0ğ›¾0\gamma\geq 0italic_Î³ â‰¥ 0, as the set of optimal solutions to the following constrained version of MaxS-EFT with bounded magnitude:

MaxS-Mâ¢(Î³)=argâ¢maxMaxS-Mğ›¾argmax\displaystyle\texttt{MaxS-M}(\gamma)=\operatorname*{arg\,max}MaxS-M ( italic_Î³ ) = start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_max end_OPERATOR âˆ‘iâˆˆ[nT]ğ‘¸iTâ‹…(ğ‘«YiT+ğš«YiT)subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡â‹…subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘‡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‡subscriptğš«superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‡\displaystyle\sum_{i\in[n_{T}]}{\bm{Q}}^{T}_{i}\cdot({\bm{D}}_{Y_{i}^{T}}+{\bm% {\Delta}}_{Y_{i}^{T}})âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
s.t. ğš«âˆˆâ„›nÃ—d,â€–ğš«iâ€–â‰¤Î³âˆ€iâˆˆ[n].formulae-sequenceğš«superscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ‘‘formulae-sequencenormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–ğ›¾for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›\displaystyle\;\,{\bm{\Delta}}\in\mathcal{R}^{n\times d},\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|% \leq\gamma\quad\forall i\in[n].bold_Î” âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_Î³ âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] .

A ğš«âˆˆMaxS-Mâ¢(Î³)ğš«MaxS-Mğ›¾{\bm{\Delta}}\in\texttt{MaxS-M}(\gamma)bold_Î” âˆˆ MaxS-M ( italic_Î³ ) changes data embeddings by at most Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ while maximizing the similarity between training queries and their ground-truth answer. We set Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ to maximize the validation accuracy after fine-tuning with ğš«âˆˆMaxS-Mâ¢(Î³)ğš«MaxS-Mğ›¾{\bm{\Delta}}\in\texttt{MaxS-M}(\gamma)bold_Î” âˆˆ MaxS-M ( italic_Î³ ):

max\displaystyle\maxroman_max âˆ‘iâˆˆ[nV]â„iVâ¢(ğš«)subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğš«\displaystyle\sum_{i\in[n_{V}]}\mathcal{I}_{i}^{V}({\bm{\Delta}})âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_Î” )
s.t. ğš«âˆˆMaxS-Mâ¢(Î³),Î³â‰¥0.formulae-sequenceğš«MaxS-Mğ›¾ğ›¾0\displaystyle{\bm{\Delta}}\in\texttt{MaxS-M}(\gamma),\gamma\geq 0.bold_Î” âˆˆ MaxS-M ( italic_Î³ ) , italic_Î³ â‰¥ 0 .

â„iVâ¢(ğš«)superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğš«\mathcal{I}_{i}^{V}({\bm{\Delta}})caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_Î” ) denotes â„isubscriptâ„ğ‘–\mathcal{I}_{i}caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see Eq.Â 1) on the validation set ğ‘¸V,YVsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘Œğ‘‰{\bm{Q}}^{V},Y^{V}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, so âˆ‘iâˆˆ[nV]â„iVâ¢(ğš«)subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğš«\sum_{i\in[n_{V}]}\mathcal{I}_{i}^{V}({\bm{\Delta}})âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_Î” ) is the validation accuracy after fine-tuning with ğš«ğš«{\bm{\Delta}}bold_Î”. This problem is referred to as Bi-level Maximization with bounded Magnitude, BiMax-M. We denote the optimal solution to BiMax-M by ğš«Msuperscriptğš«ğ‘€{\bm{\Delta}}^{M}bold_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

\name

-M. \name-M is an algorithm that optimally solves BiMax-M:

Theorem 2.

There exists an algorithm, referred to as \name-M, that optimally solves BiMax-M in Oâ¢(nVâ¢(nâ¢d+logâ¡nV)+nTâ¢d)ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡ğ‘‘O(n_{V}(nd+\log n_{V})+n_{T}d)italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_n italic_d + roman_log italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ). Specifically, \name-M sets ğš«Msuperscriptğš«ğ‘€{\bm{\Delta}}^{M}bold_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as

ğš«iM=Î³âˆ—â¢ğ‘®iâ€–ğ‘®iâ€–,whereâ¢ğ‘®i=âˆ‘jâˆˆ[nT]ğ•€â¢[i=YjT]â¢ğ‘¸jT,âˆ€iâˆˆ[n],formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğš«ğ‘–ğ‘€superscriptğ›¾subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–formulae-sequencewheresubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡ğ•€delimited-[]ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘—ğ‘‡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘‡ğ‘—for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›\displaystyle{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}^{M}=\gamma^{*}\frac{{\bm{G}}_{i}}{\|{\bm{G}}_{i% }\|},\quad\text{where}\;\;{\bm{G}}_{i}=\sum_{j\in[n_{T}]}\mathds{I}[i=Y_{j}^{T% }]{\bm{Q}}^{T}_{j},\quad\forall i\in[n],bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG , where bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_I [ italic_i = italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] , (3)

and ğ•€ğ•€\mathds{I}blackboard_I is the indicator function with a predicate argument, for an optimally chosen scalar Î³âˆ—superscriptğ›¾\gamma^{*}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Eq.Â 3 presents the simple update rule used by \name-M to fine-tune data embeddings, using which the fine-tuned embeddings are computed as ğ‘«âˆ—=ğ‘«+ğš«Msuperscriptğ‘«ğ‘«superscriptğš«ğ‘€{\bm{D}}^{*}={\bm{D}}+{\bm{\Delta}}^{M}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_D + bold_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Observe that ğ‘®isubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–{\bm{G}}_{i}bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the sum of query embeddings whose ground-truth answer is ğ‘«isubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–{\bm{D}}_{i}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so that data embeddings are moved towards the queries for which they are the ground-truth answers. We also note that Oâ¢(nTâ¢d)ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡ğ‘‘O(n_{T}d)italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ) is the complexity of a single iteration over training data, and Oâ¢(nVâ¢nâ¢d)ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘‘O(n_{V}nd)italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_d ) is the complexity of calculating validation accuracy once. Thus, ignoring the log term, the above time complexity is equal to a single training and validation iteration for parametric approaches (i.e., Adaptors or PTFT), and has smaller constant factors since it does not perform any model forward passes.

The optimal Î³âˆ—superscriptğ›¾\gamma^{*}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in Eq.Â 3 is calculated by solving linear inequalities resulting from the definition of â„iVsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘‰\mathcal{I}_{i}^{V}caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We provide an overview here and leave the details to Appx.Â B.2. First, note that MaxS-Mâ¢(Î³)=Î³â¢ğ‘®â€–ğ‘®â€–MaxS-Mğ›¾ğ›¾ğ‘®normğ‘®\texttt{MaxS-M}(\gamma)=\gamma\frac{{\bm{G}}}{\|{\bm{G}}\|}MaxS-M ( italic_Î³ ) = italic_Î³ divide start_ARG bold_italic_G end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G âˆ¥ end_ARG, found using the KKT points of the optimization problem. Thus, BiMax-M reduces to finding a Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ that maximizes âˆ‘iâˆˆ[nV]â„iVâ¢(Î³â¢ğ‘®â€–ğ‘®â€–)subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ›¾ğ‘®normğ‘®\sum_{i\in[n_{V}]}\mathcal{I}_{i}^{V}(\gamma\frac{{\bm{G}}}{\|{\bm{G}}\|})âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î³ divide start_ARG bold_italic_G end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G âˆ¥ end_ARG ). For each iâˆˆ[nV]ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰i\in[n_{V}]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], substituting ğš«=Î³â¢ğ‘®â€–ğ‘®â€–ğš«ğ›¾ğ‘®normğ‘®{\bm{\Delta}}=\gamma\frac{{\bm{G}}}{\|{\bm{G}}\|}bold_Î” = italic_Î³ divide start_ARG bold_italic_G end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G âˆ¥ end_ARG into the definition of â„iVâ¢(ğš«)superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğš«\mathcal{I}_{i}^{V}({\bm{\Delta}})caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_Î” ) in Eq.Â 1, we have â„iVâ¢(Î³â¢ğ‘®â€–ğ‘®â€–)=1superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ›¾ğ‘®normğ‘®1\mathcal{I}_{i}^{V}(\gamma\frac{{\bm{G}}}{\|{\bm{G}}\|})=1caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î³ divide start_ARG bold_italic_G end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G âˆ¥ end_ARG ) = 1 if the following holds, and zero otherwise:

ğ‘¸iVâ‹…(ğ‘«Yi+Î³â¢ğ‘®YiVâ€–ğ‘®YiVâ€–)>ğ‘¸iVâ‹…(ğ‘«j+Î³â¢ğ‘®jâ€–ğ‘®jâ€–),âˆ€jâˆˆ[n]âˆ–YiV.formulae-sequenceâ‹…superscriptsubscriptğ‘¸ğ‘–ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘«subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ›¾subscriptğ‘®superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‰normsubscriptğ‘®superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‰â‹…superscriptsubscriptğ‘¸ğ‘–ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘«ğ‘—ğ›¾subscriptğ‘®ğ‘—normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘—for-allğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‰\displaystyle{\bm{Q}}_{i}^{V}\cdot({\bm{D}}_{Y_{i}}+\gamma\frac{{\bm{G}}_{Y_{i% }^{V}}}{\|{\bm{G}}_{Y_{i}^{V}}\|})>{\bm{Q}}_{i}^{V}\cdot({\bm{D}}_{j}+\gamma% \frac{{\bm{G}}_{j}}{\|{\bm{G}}_{j}\|}),\quad\forall j\in[n]\setminus Y_{i}^{V}.bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î³ divide start_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG ) > bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î³ divide start_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG ) , âˆ€ italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_n ] âˆ– italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (4)

Eq.Â 4 is a set of inequalities in Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. Denote the solution to the inequalities by Iisubscriptğ¼ğ‘–I_{i}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so that Î³âˆˆIiğ›¾subscriptğ¼ğ‘–\gamma\in I_{i}italic_Î³ âˆˆ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if and only if â„iVâ¢(Î³â¢ğ‘®â€–ğ‘®â€–)=1superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ›¾ğ‘®normğ‘®1\mathcal{I}_{i}^{V}(\gamma\frac{{\bm{G}}}{\|{\bm{G}}\|})=1caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Î³ divide start_ARG bold_italic_G end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G âˆ¥ end_ARG ) = 1. Since the inequalities are linear in Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, Iisubscriptğ¼ğ‘–I_{i}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an interval in â„›â„›\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R. Consequently,

Î³âˆ—=argâ¢maxÎ³â¢âˆ‘iâˆˆnVğ•€â¢[Î³âˆˆIi],superscriptğ›¾subscriptargmaxğ›¾subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰ğ•€delimited-[]ğ›¾subscriptğ¼ğ‘–\displaystyle\gamma^{*}=\operatorname*{arg\,max}_{\gamma}\sum_{i\in n_{V}}% \mathds{I}[\gamma\in I_{i}],italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_max end_OPERATOR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_I [ italic_Î³ âˆˆ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] , (5)

and the solution to Eq.Â 5 is a Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ that intersects the most number of intervals across all Iisubscriptğ¼ğ‘–I_{i}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, iâˆˆ[nV]ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰i\in[n_{V}]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], which can be found by a single iteration over the intervals after sorting their start and end points.

3.2.2 \name-N: \name with Normalized Embeddings

\name

-N additionally constrains the norm of the fine-tuned embedding. This constraint serves as an additional regularization, helping with out-of-distribution generalization (see Sec.4.2).

Optimization Formulation. Analogous to MaxS-Mâ¢(Î³)MaxS-Mğ›¾\texttt{MaxS-M}(\gamma)MaxS-M ( italic_Î³ ) but with an added constraint, we define MaxS-Nâ¢(Î³)MaxS-Nğ›¾\texttt{MaxS-N}(\gamma)MaxS-N ( italic_Î³ ) as the optimal solution to the following optimization problem:

MaxS-Nâ¢(Î³)=argâ¢maxMaxS-Nğ›¾argmax\displaystyle\texttt{MaxS-N}(\gamma)=\operatorname*{arg\,max}MaxS-N ( italic_Î³ ) = start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_max end_OPERATOR âˆ‘iâˆˆ[nT]ğ‘¸iTâ‹…(ğ‘«YiT+ğš«YiT)subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡â‹…subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘‡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‡subscriptğš«superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‡\displaystyle\sum_{i\in[n_{T}]}{\bm{Q}}^{T}_{i}\cdot({\bm{D}}_{Y_{i}^{T}}+{\bm% {\Delta}}_{Y_{i}^{T}})âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
s.t. ğš«âˆˆâ„›nÃ—d,â€–ğš«iâ€–2â‰¤Î³,â€–ğ‘«i+ğš«iâ€–=1âˆ€iâˆˆ[n].formulae-sequenceğš«superscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ‘‘formulae-sequencesuperscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2ğ›¾formulae-sequencenormsubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğš«ğ‘–1for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›\displaystyle\;\,{\bm{\Delta}}\in\mathcal{R}^{n\times d},\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|% ^{2}\leq\gamma,{\color[rgb]{0.0,0.42,0.24}\|{\bm{D}}_{i}+{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|=1% }\quad\forall i\in[n].bold_Î” âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Î³ , âˆ¥ bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 1 âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] .

To find a suitable Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, we solve the same optimization problem as BiMax-M, except that we replace MaxS-Mâ¢(Î³)MaxS-Mğ›¾\texttt{MaxS-M}(\gamma)MaxS-M ( italic_Î³ ) with MaxS-Nâ¢(Î³)MaxS-Nğ›¾\texttt{MaxS-N}(\gamma)MaxS-N ( italic_Î³ ). We call this problem Bi-level Maximization with Normalized embeddings, BiMax-N, and refer to its optimal solution as ğš«Nsuperscriptğš«ğ‘{\bm{\Delta}}^{N}bold_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

\name

-N. \name-N is an algorithm that optimally solves BiMax-N:

Theorem 3.

There exists an algorithm, referred to as \name-N, that optimally solves BiMax-N in Oâ¢(nVâ¢(nâ¢d+logâ¡nV)+nTâ¢d)ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡ğ‘‘O(n_{V}(nd+\log n_{V})+n_{T}d)italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_n italic_d + roman_log italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ). Specifically, \name-N sets ğš«Nsuperscriptğš«ğ‘{\bm{\Delta}}^{N}bold_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as

ğš«iN={ğ‘®iâ€–ğ‘®iâ€–âˆ’ğ‘«i,ifâ¢ğ‘®iâ‹…ğ‘«iâ€–ğ‘®iâ€–â‰¥1âˆ’Î³âˆ—2Î³âˆ—â¢(4âˆ’Î³âˆ—)2â¢ğ’iâˆ’Î³âˆ—2â¢ğ‘«i,otherwise,superscriptsubscriptğš«ğ‘–ğ‘casessubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–ifâ‹…subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–1superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ›¾4superscriptğ›¾2subscriptğ’ğ‘–superscriptğ›¾2subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–otherwise,{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}^{N}=\begin{cases*}\frac{{\bm{G}}_{i}}{\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|}-{\bm% {D}}_{i},&$\textnormal{if}\;\frac{{\bm{G}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i}}{\|{\bm{G}}_{i% }\|}\geq 1-\frac{\gamma^{*}}{2}$\\ \frac{\sqrt{\gamma^{*}(4-\gamma^{*})}}{2}{\bm{Z}}_{i}-\frac{\gamma^{*}}{2}{\bm% {D}}_{i},&{otherwise,}\end{cases*}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG - bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL if divide start_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 4 - italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL otherwise, end_CELL end_ROW (6)

where

ğ’i=ğ‘®iâˆ’(ğ‘«iâ‹…ğ‘®i)â¢ğ‘«iâ€–ğ‘®iâˆ’(ğ‘«iâ‹…ğ‘®i)â¢ğ‘«iâ€–,subscriptğ’ğ‘–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–â‹…subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–â‹…subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–{\bm{Z}}_{i}=\frac{{\bm{G}}_{i}-({\bm{D}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{G}}_{i}){\bm{D}}_{i}}{% \|{\bm{G}}_{i}-({\bm{D}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{G}}_{i}){\bm{D}}_{i}\|},bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG ,

and ğ†isubscriptğ†ğ‘–{\bm{G}}_{i}bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is as defined in Eq.Â 3, for an optimally chosen scalar Î³âˆ—superscriptğ›¾\gamma^{*}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Eq.Â 6 is the update rule used by \name-N to fine-tune data embeddings, using which the fine-tuned embeddings are obtained as ğ‘«âˆ—=ğ‘«+ğš«Nsuperscriptğ‘«ğ‘«superscriptğš«ğ‘{\bm{D}}^{*}={\bm{D}}+{\bm{\Delta}}^{N}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_italic_D + bold_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This moves the data embedding on the unit ball (to satisfy â€–ğ‘«i+ğš«iâ€–=1normsubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğš«ğ‘–1\|{\bm{D}}_{i}+{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|=1âˆ¥ bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 1) between ğ‘«isubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–{\bm{D}}_{i}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ‘®iâ€–ğ‘®iâ€–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–\frac{{\bm{G}}_{i}}{\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|}divide start_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG, where ğ‘®iâ€–ğ‘®iâ€–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–\frac{{\bm{G}}_{i}}{\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|}divide start_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG is the normalized sum of embeddings of queries whose ground-truth answer is ğ‘«isubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–{\bm{D}}_{i}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Î³âˆ—superscriptğ›¾\gamma^{*}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT determines how much to move the embedding, and ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–{\bm{Z}}_{i}bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT determines the direction. ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–{\bm{Z}}_{i}bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the normalized projection of ğ‘®isubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–{\bm{G}}_{i}bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT onto the tangent plane of the unit ball at ğ‘«isubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–{\bm{D}}_{i}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so that moving in the direction of ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–{\bm{Z}}_{i}bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT maximally increases MaxS-N objective.

Finding the optimal Î³âˆ—superscriptğ›¾\gamma^{*}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is similar to \name-M, where we first use KKT to solve MaxS-Nâ¢(Î³)MaxS-Nğ›¾\texttt{MaxS-N}(\gamma)MaxS-N ( italic_Î³ ) and substitute the resulting ğš«ğš«{\bm{\Delta}}bold_Î” into the definition of â„iVsubscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‰ğ‘–\mathcal{I}^{V}_{i}caligraphic_I start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Eq.Â 1. The optimal Î³âˆ—superscriptğ›¾\gamma^{*}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is then found as the value that satisfies the maximum number of the resulting inequalities. The resulting inequalities are, in this case, quadratic due to Î³â¢(4âˆ’Î³)ğ›¾4ğ›¾\sqrt{\gamma(4-\gamma)}square-root start_ARG italic_Î³ ( 4 - italic_Î³ ) end_ARG in the solution to MaxS-Nâ¢(Î³)MaxS-Nğ›¾\texttt{MaxS-N}(\gamma)MaxS-N ( italic_Î³ ), but can still be solved in closed-form. Nevertheless, from a practical perspective, solving the quadratic equations is tedious as it requires considering various special cases. We observed that performing a grid search to find Î³âˆ—superscriptğ›¾\gamma^{*}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that maximizes validation accuracy finds good enough solutions and is almost as efficient. Thus, in our experiments, we use this practical implementation.

4 Experiments

We present results on standard text and image retrieval benchmarks and multiple pre-trained models. We present our main experimental results here, but for the sake of space, defer more detailed results and ablation studies to Appx.Â E.

Datasets. For text retrieval datasets we use 7 standard datasets: SciFacts (Wadden etÂ al., 2020), Fever (Fever, 2024), ArguAna (Arguana, 2024) (we use their BEIR (Thakur etÂ al., 2021) versions), TriviaQAÂ Joshi etÂ al. (2017), HotpotQAÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2018), and Natural Questions(Kwiatkowski etÂ al., 2019) (we use their KILT (Petroni etÂ al., 2021) versions), and NF-Corpus (Boteva etÂ al., 2016) (although all datasets have a BEIR version, we use non-BEIR versions whenever that is larger). We use the datasets as is, without any preprocessing step, except for datasets from KILT, where we only use Wikipedia pages that contain an answer to at least one query (i.e., pages where we expect fine-tuning to have an impact). For image retrieval, we use COCOÂ (Lin etÂ al., 2014) (we use the dataset from 2014) and FlickrÂ (Young etÂ al., 2014) datasets. We use image captions as queries to retrieve the corresponding image. For all text and image datasets, we use 0.7-0.1-0.2 train, validation and test split, but limit test and validation sizes to at most 10,000 queries if there is more. Statistics about data and query size are presented in TableÂ 2.

Pre-Trained Models. We report results on fine-tuning embeddings for 5 different pre-trained models, 3 for text and 2 for image retrieval, where we consider models of different sizes and embedding dimensions. For text, we use BGE-small (Xiao etÂ al., 2023) with 33M parameters and embedding dimension 384, GTE-large (Li etÂ al., 2023b) with 434M parameters and embedding dimension 1024 and OpenAIâ€™s text-embedding-large-3 (OpenAI, 2024a), a closed-source model with embedding dimensions 3072. The three models are respectively referred to as BGE-S, GTE-L and TE3-L. For image retrieval, we use two CLIP variants (Radford etÂ al., 2021), ViT-B/32 and ViT-L/14, which have, respectively, 151M and 427M parameters and 512 and 768 embedding dimensions. We respectively call them CLIP-B and CLIP-L.

Baselines. We report results using the embeddings without fine-tuning, called No Fine-Tuning, in addition to training Adaptors and fine-tuning the pre-trained model, referred to as PTFT (see Appx.Â E.1 for implementation details). Due to computational constraints, we report results for the latter only for the small open-source model BGE-S in our main experiments. For both, we present two versions. By default, we use the Multiple Negative Ranking (MNR) loss (Henderson etÂ al., 2017) for training, which is the standard contrastive fine-tuning loss when positive query/answer pairs are available, suggested by SentenceTransformers (SentenceTransformers, 2024a) and used by LlamaIndex (LlamaIndex, 2024d) for fine-tuning (although LlamaIndex only uses a single positive example per queryÂ (LlamaIndex, 2024e)). Despite our hyperparameter tuning effort, we observed no accuracy improvements on some datasets through fine-tuning with this loss (see TableÂ 6). We then modified the loss, so that only negative samples whose cosine similarity is at least equal to a threshold are included in the loss (see E.1 for details), which improved accuracy on some datasets but worsened it on other. We use the suffix -L to denote the baselines using this modified loss. We report results using this loss to gain more insight into the baselineâ€™s behavior. We use cosine similarity as the retrieval distance metric for No Fine-Tuning, Adaptor, and PTFT.

Metrics. We report typical metrics Recall@kğ‘˜kitalic_k (R@kğ‘˜kitalic_k for short) and NDCG@kğ‘˜kitalic_k with k=10ğ‘˜10k=10italic_k = 10 by default, following MTEB benchmarkÂ (Muennighoff etÂ al., 2022). We also report Recall@1, the validation metric, and the change in NDCG@kğ‘˜kitalic_k compared with No Fine-Tuning in parenthesis (+/-).

4.1 Baseline Results

Summary of results. TablesÂ 3-5 present our accuracy results averaged across all text or image datasets for different models. TableÂ 6 presents the per dataset results for BGE-S. The per dataset results for other models followed similar trends and are deferred to Appx.Â E.2.

As TablesÂ 3-5 show, both \name-M and \name-N provide significant accuracy gains, providing up to 14.3% NDCG@10 boost over No Fine-Tuning while PTFT and Adaptor only improve NDCG@10 up to 4.0%, when averaged across datasets, for both text and image retrieval. Interestingly, the accuracy gains from \name-M and \name-N depends on the pre-trained model. GTE-L outperforms TE3-L without fine-tuning, but using \name TE3-L outperforms GTE-L.

Moreover, TableÂ 5 shows the total fine-tuning time to run BGE-S on our text datasets (i.e., time obtain the associated results in TableÂ 3) using an Nvidia A100 GPU as well as using 32 core Intel Broadwell CPUs. The reported time excludes the time to embed the data records (which is the same across all methods). \name variants run in 1-2 minutes with GPU and in up to 11 minutes using CPUs, which is, respectively, more than 3 and 11 times faster than Adaptor and more than 200 times faster than PTFT, which cannot be run on CPUs in a reasonable time-frame. For both Adaptor and PTFT, the reported run times are for optimized implementations that include early stopping and optimizations for efficient calculation of validation accuracy (see Appx.Â E.1).

Detailed Results. TableÂ 6 shows the detailed retrieval accuracy on text datasets for BGE-S. \name significantly outperforms parametric methods on almost all datasets. \name-N outperforms \name-M on most datasets, showing the benefit of constraining embeddings to be normalized.

The results show that parametric approaches are unreliable and fail to provide significant accuracy improvements despite requiring significantly more computational resources. The reported results are after hyperparameter tuning as well as tweaking the loss function (i.e., -L variants). We observed that the latter does help improve (and sometimes worsen) accuracy for parametric approaches on some datasets, with Adaptor-L and PTFT-L providing accuracy improvements on Fever and HotpotQA where Adaptor and PTFT provided none. Meanwhile, \name consistently provides significant accuracy boosts without any hyperparameter tuning. We provide a detailed discussion of the failure modes of the parametric approaches in Appx.Â E.3.

To better understand the results, we remark on the performance on ArguAna and Fever datasets. Fever, where \name-M performs better than \name-N has a skewed label distribution, where the same paragraph is the correct answer for many queries. This allows for setting the magnitude of the embeddings based on label distribution, assigning embeddings with larger magnitudes to more frequently accessed passages. Such an assignment can improve the accuracy when the label distribution is fixed and skewed, but leads to worse generalization when there is no skew (as the results on other datasets in TableÂ 6 show) or when there is a distribution shift (see Sec.Â 4.2). Finally, in ArguAna, each data record is a factual argument and each query provides an argument and asks for a counterargument to the given argument. In such a setting, to improve accuracy, we expect larger systematic changes to the embedding space to be required to be able to retrieve the semantically opposite (instead of similar). Learning such changes from a small training set is challenging and perhaps a more task-specific methodology is required for this dataset.

4.2 Out-of-distribution Generalization

Next, we study the impact of fine-tuning on out-of-distribution queries. In this experiment, separately for each dataset, we use K-means to cluster all the queries in two clusters, referred to as C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We split C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into 3 sets, C1trainsuperscriptsubscriptğ¶1trainC_{1}^{\text{train}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT train end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, C1valsuperscriptsubscriptğ¶1valC_{1}^{\text{val}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT val end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and C1testsuperscriptsubscriptğ¶1testC_{1}^{\text{test}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT test end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where C1trainsuperscriptsubscriptğ¶1trainC_{1}^{\text{train}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT train end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and C1valsuperscriptsubscriptğ¶1valC_{1}^{\text{val}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT val end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are used for training and validation. We report test results on C1testsuperscriptsubscriptğ¶1testC_{1}^{\text{test}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT test end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as in-distribution and on C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as out-of-distribution results.

Average results across text datasets and with BGE-S model are shown in TableÂ 4. As the table shows, \name-N performs the best on the out-of-distribution test set, even outperforming No Fine-Tuning, while providing a significant accuracy boost on the in-distribution samples. Although \name-M performs well on in-distribution samples, its performance deteriorates on out-of-distribution queries. The main difference between \name-M and \name-N is that \name-Mâ€™s embeddings are not normalized. Thus, when retrieving top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k results using inner product as similarity metric, a fine-tuned embedding with large magnitude can adversely impact the query answers for out-of-distribution queries. However, by keeping embeddings normalized, \name-N ensures fine-tuned embeddings do not change the answer to queries that are far from fine-tuned data records, thus avoiding performance degradation on out-of-distribution queries. Finally, Adaptor provides little gain on in-distribution queries, while worsening accuracy on out-of-distribution samples.

4.3 Ablation Study

We provide an ablation study to better understand the impact of various constraints in \name. In addition to \name-M and \name-N, we present \name-M+N, which performs normalization on the output of \name-M. That is, instead of incorporating normalization as a constraint in the optimization problem, \name-M+N simply normalizes the embeddings after performing \name-M. We also present \name-NU, which is a variation of \name-N that only includes the normalization constraint, but not the constraint on the magnitude of the change in the embeddings (the solution is equivalent to the first branch of Eq.Â 6).

TableÂ 8 shows the results of comparing the above variants across text datasets using the BGE-S model. The table shows normalizing the embeddings as part of the optimization (\name-N) is better than simply normalizing the output after optimization (\name-M+N), although both work better than using unnormalized embeddings (\name-M). Moreover, allowing the magnitude of change to the embeddings to be unbounded (\name-NU) performs worse than all other variants, showing the benefit of constraining how much embeddings can change during fine-tuning. Overall, comparing \name-N, No Fine-Tuning, and all other variants, we see that the benefits of \name-N come from a combination of all design choices made.

5 Related Work

Decades of research has explored various retrieval methods, including sparse (Robertson etÂ al., 2009), dense (Karpukhin etÂ al., 2020), late interaction Khattab & Zaharia (2020) and generative retrieval Tay etÂ al. (2022) to name a few. Compared with such retrieval paradigms, kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval has recently gained increased popularity (see Zhao etÂ al. (2024) for a survey of recent studies) due to its simplicity and efficiency. kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval uses embeddings from pre-trained models, thus avoiding the need for extensive training on the dataset in hand, and performs retrieval through a simple vector index look-up avoiding expensive model inference at query time.

This paper focuses on improving kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval accuracy given access to a pre-trained embedding model. Related work can be divided into two categories. The first category, including this paper, aims to improve the embeddings through fine-tuning for the specific dataset and query workload. Fine-tuning the pre-trained model itself, through a similar training strategy used during pre-training is possible, Zhao etÂ al. (2024); Tang etÂ al. (2022); Tam etÂ al. (2022); Liu etÂ al. (2021a); Pires etÂ al. (2019); Yu etÂ al. (2022); Ma etÂ al. (2024), but requires access to the model parameters, is computationally expensive and incurs extra hosting and maintenance costs the fine-tuned models at deployment time. A common alternative in practice is to train adaptors (SuvanshÂ Sanjeev, 2024; LlamaIndex, 2024b) to transform the output of the models. As our experiments show, adaptors provide limited accuracy gains. On the other hand, our approach, \name, is efficient, model agnostic, does not require hosting and maintaining any model at deployment time, and provides a significant accuracy boost. Work in the second category, orthogonal to this paper, modify the retrieval algorithm to improve accuracy, e.g., through query rewriting, reranking, etc. (see Zhao etÂ al. (2024); Gao etÂ al. (2023) for a survey). Notable examples include Gao etÂ al. (2022), which rewrites the queries as a hypothetical documents, Sarthi etÂ al. (2024), which adds summary text chunks to the dataset to improve retrieval, Sachan etÂ al. (2022) which reranks passages based on probability of observing the query, and Lin etÂ al. (2024) which extracts document structure for query answering.

Beyond retrieval, our work is related to recent work on fine-tuning pre-trained models for various purposesÂ (Ouyang etÂ al., 2022; Rafailov etÂ al., 2024; Ziegler etÂ al., 2019; Zhang etÂ al., 2024; Patil etÂ al., 2023), but shows the novel insight that non-parametric fine-tuning of model output, instead of fine-tuning model parameters, can provide significant accuracy improvements. Similar to Ouyang etÂ al. (2022); Rafailov etÂ al. (2024); Ziegler etÂ al. (2019), our optimization constrains how much model output can change during fine-tuning. In \name, this constraint represents the intuition that among all fine-tuned embeddings that achieve a specific training loss, one with the least change from non-fine-tuned embedding should be preferred. Although this intuition can be broadly applicable to fine-tuning, the KL-divergence constraint in Ouyang etÂ al. (2022); Ziegler etÂ al. (2019) has additional significance due to the use of a reward model.

6 Conclusion

We studied the problem of fine-tuning embeddings to improve kğ‘˜kitalic_k-NN retrieval accuracy. We presented \name, a novel non-parametric approach to embedding fine-tuning that is efficient, provides significant accuracy boosts and does not require any model hosting or maintenance at deployment time. Our experimental results show \name improves accuracy by up to 16.0% compared with existing methods and up to 24.4% compared with no fine-tuning. Future work includes incorporating \name inside vector databases and generating and maintaining query sets for fine-tuning.

Appendix A Appendix Overview

This appendix is organized as follows:

  • â€¢

    Appx.Â B contains the proofs of the theoretical results in the paper.

  • â€¢

    Appx.Â C contains other practical \name variants.

  • â€¢

    Appx.Â D discusses the extension of \name to multi-label settings.

  • â€¢

    Appx.Â E provides details about the experimental setting, and provides additional experiments.

Appendix B Proofs

Appx.Â B.1-B.3, respectively, provide the proofs of Theorems.Â 1-3. The proofs of technical lemmas are presented in Appx.Â B.4

B.1 Proof of TheoremÂ 1

We show a reduction from homogeneous maximum feasible linear subsystem, Max-FLS, shown to be NP-Hard in Amaldi & Kann (1995). We first formally state the decision version of the problem.

Problem 2 (Homogeneous Max-FLS).

Given a linear system ğ€â¢ğ±<ğŸğ€ğ±0{\bm{A}}{\bm{x}}<\mathbf{0}bold_italic_A bold_italic_x < bold_0, where ğ€ğ€{\bm{A}}bold_italic_A is of size sÃ—tğ‘ ğ‘¡s\times titalic_s Ã— italic_t, and an integer Kğ¾Kitalic_K with 1<K<s1ğ¾ğ‘ 1<K<s1 < italic_K < italic_s, does there exist a solution ğ±âˆˆâ„›tğ±superscriptâ„›ğ‘¡{\bm{x}}\in\mathcal{R}^{t}bold_italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfying at least Kğ¾Kitalic_K inequalities of the system?

We show a reduction from Homogeneous Max-FLS to the decision version of MaxA-EFT. The decision version of MaxA-EFT asks whether there exists ğš«ğš«{\bm{\Delta}}bold_Î” such that the training accuracy is at least Kğ¾Kitalic_K, i.e., whether at least Kğ¾Kitalic_K different â„iâ¢(ğš«)subscriptâ„ğ‘–ğš«\mathcal{I}_{i}({\bm{\Delta}})caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_Î” ), iâˆˆ[nT]ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡i\in[n_{T}]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] can be satisfied.

Given ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bm{A}}bold_italic_A, the reduction defines an instance of MaxA-EFT by specifying ğ‘«ğ‘«{\bm{D}}bold_italic_D, ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}}bold_italic_Q, and Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y. Specifically, we let ğ‘¸=ğ‘¨ğ‘¸ğ‘¨{\bm{Q}}={\bm{A}}bold_italic_Q = bold_italic_A, ğ‘«=ğŸâˆˆâ„›2Ã—tğ‘«0superscriptâ„›2ğ‘¡{\bm{D}}=\mathbf{0}\in\mathcal{R}^{2\times t}bold_italic_D = bold_0 âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 Ã— italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (i.e., a 2Ã—t2ğ‘¡2\times t2 Ã— italic_t matrix only consisting of zeros) and Y={Y1,â€¦,Ys}ğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘Œ1â€¦subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ Y=\{Y_{1},...,Y_{s}\}italic_Y = { italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, Yi=0â¢âˆ€iâˆˆ[s]subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–0for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘ Y_{i}=0\;\forall i\in[s]italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_s ] (i.e., this instance only has 2 data records, embedding dimension is tğ‘¡titalic_t and there are sğ‘ sitalic_s training queries).

We next show that there exists ğš«ğš«{\bm{\Delta}}bold_Î” so that the training accuracy of MaxA-EFT is at least Kğ¾Kitalic_K if and only if there exists a solution ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}}bold_italic_x to Homogeneous Max-FLS satisfying at least Kğ¾Kitalic_K inequalities of the system.

Observe that, by the above construction, â„iâ¢(ğš«)subscriptâ„ğ‘–ğš«\mathcal{I}_{i}({\bm{\Delta}})caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_Î” ) is satisfied if and only if

ğ‘¸iâ‹…(ğš«1âˆ’ğš«0)<0.â‹…subscriptğ‘¸ğ‘–subscriptğš«1subscriptğš«00{\bm{Q}}_{i}\cdot({\bm{\Delta}}_{1}-{\bm{\Delta}}_{0})<0.bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… ( bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) < 0 .

Suppose the training accuracy is at least Kğ¾Kitalic_K for some ğš«ğš«{\bm{\Delta}}bold_Î”. Let ğ’™=ğš«1âˆ’ğš«0ğ’™subscriptğš«1subscriptğš«0{\bm{x}}={\bm{\Delta}}_{1}-{\bm{\Delta}}_{0}bold_italic_x = bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and let {i1,â€¦,iK}subscriptğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘–ğ¾\{i_{1},...,i_{K}\}{ italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } be the index of Kğ¾Kitalic_K training samples answered correctly. Thus, we have ğ‘¨iâ‹…ğ’™<0â‹…subscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–ğ’™0{\bm{A}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{x}}<0bold_italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_x < 0 for all iâˆˆ{i1,â€¦,iK}ğ‘–subscriptğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘–ğ¾i\in\{i_{1},...,i_{K}\}italic_i âˆˆ { italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, showing the existing Kğ¾Kitalic_K inequalities in the subsystem that are satisfied.

Conversely, assume some ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}}bold_italic_x satisfies at least Kğ¾Kitalic_K inequalities in the subsystem. Let ğš«0=ğŸsubscriptğš«00{\bm{\Delta}}_{0}=\mathbf{0}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_0 and ğš«1=ğ’™subscriptğš«1ğ’™{\bm{\Delta}}_{1}={\bm{x}}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_x. We have that at least Kğ¾Kitalic_K inequalities in

ğ‘¸â¢ğš«1<ğŸğ‘¸subscriptğš«10{\bm{Q}}{\bm{\Delta}}_{1}<\mathbf{0}bold_italic_Q bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < bold_0

are satisfied, so that the training accuracy is at least Kğ¾Kitalic_K. The reduction is polynomial time, thus showing MaxA-EFT is NP-hard.âˆ

B.2 Proof of TheoremÂ 2

Setup. Recall that for any iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ],

ğ‘®i=âˆ‘jâˆˆ[nT]ğ•€â¢[i=YjT]â¢ğ‘¸jT,subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡ğ•€delimited-[]ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘—ğ‘‡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘‡ğ‘—{\bm{G}}_{i}=\sum_{j\in[n_{T}]}\mathds{I}[i=Y_{j}^{T}]{\bm{Q}}^{T}_{j},bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_I [ italic_i = italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

so that

argâ¡maxğš«âˆˆâ„›nÃ—dâ¢âˆ‘iâˆˆ[nT]ğ‘¸iTâ‹…(ğ‘«YiT+ğš«YiT)=argâ¡maxğš«âˆˆâ„›nÃ—dâ¢âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘®iâ‹…ğš«i=argâ¡maxğš«âˆˆâ„›nÃ—dâ¢âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n],â€–ğ‘®iâ€–â‰ 0ğ‘®iâ‹…ğš«i.ğš«superscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡â‹…subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘‡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‡subscriptğš«superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‡ğš«superscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›â‹…subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğš«ğ‘–ğš«superscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–0â‹…subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğš«ğ‘–\underset{{\bm{\Delta}}\in\mathcal{R}^{n\times d}}{\arg\max}\sum_{i\in[n_{T}]}% {\bm{Q}}^{T}_{i}\cdot({\bm{D}}_{Y_{i}^{T}}+{\bm{\Delta}}_{Y_{i}^{T}})=% \underset{{\bm{\Delta}}\in\mathcal{R}^{n\times d}}{\arg\max}\sum_{i\in[n]}{\bm% {G}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}=\underset{{\bm{\Delta}}\in\mathcal{R}^{n\times d% }}{\arg\max}\sum_{i\in[n],\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|\neq 0}{\bm{G}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{\Delta}% }_{i}.start_UNDERACCENT bold_Î” âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_arg roman_max end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_arg roman_max end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = start_UNDERACCENT bold_Î” âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_arg The proofs here use the above formulation for MaxS-M. Moreover, we set ğš«iÎ³=0superscriptsubscriptğš«ğ‘–ğ›¾0{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}^{\gamma}=\textbf{0}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î³ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 for any iğ‘–iitalic_i where â€–ğ‘®iâ€–=0normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–0\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|=0âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 0, given that they do not appear in the above objective. Note that even when ğš«iÎ³=0superscriptsubscriptğš«ğ‘–ğ›¾0{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}^{\gamma}=\textbf{0}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î³ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 for any iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ], the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th record still influences the BiMax-M objective and needs to be taken into account when solving the outer optimization in BiMax-M.

Finding MaxS-M. We first find MaxS-Mâ¢(Î³)MaxS-Mğ›¾\texttt{MaxS-M}(\gamma)MaxS-M ( italic_Î³ ) by solving the following optimization problem:
