Ii,jsubscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘—I_{i,j}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT defines an interval in â„›â„›\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R so that Î³âˆˆIi,jğ›¾subscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘—\gamma\in I_{i,j}italic_Î³ âˆˆ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT means the correct answer to the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th validation query has higher similarity to the query compared with the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th data record, for jâ‰ YiVğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‰j\neq Y_{i}^{V}italic_j â‰  italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Thus, to answer the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th query correctly, we must have Î³âˆˆIi=âˆ©jâ‰ YiVIi,jğ›¾subscriptğ¼ğ‘–subscriptğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‰subscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘—\gamma\in I_{i}=\cap_{j\neq Y_{i}^{V}}I_{i,j}italic_Î³ âˆˆ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j â‰  italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To maximize the number of queries answered correctly, after finding Iisubscriptğ¼ğ‘–I_{i}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all iğ‘–iitalic_i, we simply need to find a Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ value that intersects the most number of intervals among I1,â€¦,InVsubscriptğ¼1â€¦subscriptğ¼subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰I_{1},...,I_{n_{V}}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., argâ¡maxÎ³â¢âˆ‘IiâˆˆIğ•€â¢[Î³âˆˆIi]subscriptğ›¾subscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ¼ğ•€delimited-[]ğ›¾subscriptğ¼ğ‘–\arg\max_{\gamma}\sum_{I_{i}\in I}\mathds{I}[\gamma\in I_{i}]roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_I [ italic_Î³ âˆˆ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], where I={I1,â€¦,InV}ğ¼subscriptğ¼1â€¦subscriptğ¼subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰I=\{I_{1},...,I_{n_{V}}\}italic_I = { italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Finding a point where maximum intervals overlap is a basic algorithmic problem and can be done by a single iteration through the intervals after sorting their start and end points.

\name

-M. Alg.Â 1 presents \name-M, which formalizes the above procedure, and also incorporates the constraint Î³â‰¥0ğ›¾0\gamma\geq 0italic_Î³ â‰¥ 0. LinesÂ 6-15 find the intervals Iisubscriptğ¼ğ‘–I_{i}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, âˆ€iâˆˆ[nV]for-allğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰\forall i\in[n_{V}]âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] and add it to a list Iğ¼Iitalic_I (intersection of half intervals can be found by calculating the maximum of lower bounds and minimum of upper bounds of the intervals, done in linesÂ 9-Â 11). The algorithm returns new data embeddings by simply performing a single addition.

Time complexity. Alg.Â 1 can be implemented so that lines 11-7 with a single pass over the dataset. Therefore, finding Iisubscriptğ¼ğ‘–I_{i}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all queries (linesÂ 6-15) take Oâ¢(nVÃ—nÃ—d)ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘‘O(n_{V}\times n\times d)italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_n Ã— italic_d ). Calculating GğºGitalic_G takes time Oâ¢(nTÃ—d)ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡ğ‘‘O(n_{T}\times d)italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_d ). Finding Î³âˆ—superscriptğ›¾\gamma^{*}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in lineÂ 16 is the basic problem of finding the maximum number of overlapping ranges and can be done in Oâ¢(nVâ¢logâ¡(nV))ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰O(n_{V}\log(n_{V}))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ), by first sorting the ranges in Iğ¼Iitalic_I based on their lower bound and iteratively traversing the sorted list and keeping track of the number of overlapping ranges. Thus, Alg.Â 1 can be implemented in O(nV(nÃ—d+log(nV)+nTÃ—d)O(n_{V}(n\times d+\log(n_{V})+n_{T}\times d)italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_n Ã— italic_d + roman_log ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_d ).

B.3 Proof of TheoremÂ 3

Setup. In the discussion below, for simplicity, we assume for any iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] ğ‘®iâ‹…ğ‘«iâ‰¥0â‹…subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–0{\bm{G}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i}\geq 0bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0. Although the discussion below can be extended to consider ğ‘®iâ‹…ğ‘«i<0â‹…subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–0{\bm{G}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i}<0bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0, the results will be more tedious (see LemmaÂ 2). Moreover, in practice we expect ğ‘®iâ‹…ğ‘«iâ‰¥0â‹…subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–0{\bm{G}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i}\geq 0bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 to hold, as otherwise queries and their correct answers will have negative similarity suggesting either a poor training dataset or pre-trained embedding model. We simply set ğ‘®i=0subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–0{\bm{G}}_{i}=\textbf{0}bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 whenever ğ‘®iâ‹…ğ‘«i<0â‹…subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–0{\bm{G}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i}<0bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0. Moreover, similar to Appx.Â B.2, we rewrite the MaxS-N objective as

and set ğš«iÎ³=0superscriptsubscriptğš«ğ‘–ğ›¾0{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}^{\gamma}=\textbf{0}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î³ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 for any iğ‘–iitalic_i where â€–ğ‘®iâ€–=0.normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–0\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|=0.âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 0 . Furthermore, we assume the embeddings ğ‘«isubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–{\bm{D}}_{i}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are normalized, (i.e., â€–ğ‘«iâ€–=1normsubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–1\|{\bm{D}}_{i}\|=1âˆ¥ bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 1, âˆ€iâˆˆ[n]for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›\forall i\in[n]âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ]), or we otherwise normalize them.

Finding MaxS-N. We first find MaxS-Nâ¢(Î³)MaxS-Nğ›¾\texttt{MaxS-N}(\gamma)MaxS-N ( italic_Î³ ) by solving the following optimization problem:

argâ¡maxğš«âˆˆâ„›nÃ—dâˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘®iâ‹…ğ‘«is. t.â€–ğš«iâ€–2â‰¤Î³,âˆ€iâˆˆ[n]â€–ğš«i+ğ‘«iâ€–=1,âˆ€iâˆˆ[n].ğš«superscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›â‹…subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressions. t.superscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2ğ›¾for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–1for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›missing-subexpression\begin{array}[]{ll@{}ll}\underset{{\bm{\Delta}}\in\mathcal{R}^{n\times d}}{% \arg\max}&\sum_{i\in[n]}{\bm{G}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i}\\[10.0pt] \textnormal{s. t.}&\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|^{2}\leq\gamma,&\forall i\in[n]\\ &\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}+{\bm{D}}_{i}\|=1,&\forall i\in[n].\end{array}start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL start_UNDERACCENT bold_Î” âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_arg roman_max end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL s. t. end_CELL start_CELL âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Î³ , end_CELL start_CELL âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 1 , end_CELL start_CELL âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] . end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

In this problem, the constraints are independent for each iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ], and the objective is simply a summation across ğ‘®iâ‹…(ğ‘«i+ğš«i)â‹…subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğš«ğ‘–{\bm{G}}_{i}\cdot({\bm{D}}_{i}+{\bm{\Delta}}_{i})bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) values, so that a solution ğš«âˆ—superscriptğš«{\bm{\Delta}}^{*}bold_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is optimal for this problem if and only if for each iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ], ğš«iâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğš«ğ‘–{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}^{*}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an optimal solution to

argâ¡maxğš«âˆˆâ„›dğ‘®iâ‹…ğ‘«is. t.â€–ğš«iâ€–2â‰¤Î³,â€–ğš«i+ğ‘«iâ€–=1.ğš«superscriptâ„›ğ‘‘â‹…subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressions. t.superscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2ğ›¾missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–1missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression\begin{array}[]{ll@{}ll}\underset{{\bm{\Delta}}\in\mathcal{R}^{d}}{\arg\max}&{% \bm{G}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i}\\[10.0pt] \textnormal{s. t.}&\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|^{2}\leq\gamma,\\ &\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}+{\bm{D}}_{i}\|=1.\end{array}start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL start_UNDERACCENT bold_Î” âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_arg roman_max end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL s. t. end_CELL start_CELL âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Î³ , end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 1 . end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

Solving this problem, we have:

Lemma 2.

For any iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ], let Î¸isubscriptğœƒğ‘–\theta_{i}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the angle between ğ†isubscriptğ†ğ‘–{\bm{G}}_{i}bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğƒisubscriptğƒğ‘–{\bm{D}}_{i}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Whenever Î¸iâˆˆ[0,Ï€2]subscriptğœƒğ‘–0ğœ‹2\theta_{i}\in[0,\frac{\pi}{2}]italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ 0 , divide start_ARG italic_Ï€ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ], Î³â‰¥0ğ›¾0\gamma\geq 0italic_Î³ â‰¥ 0, â€–ğƒiâ€–=1normsubscriptğƒğ‘–1\|{\bm{D}}_{i}\|=1âˆ¥ bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 1 and â€–ğ†iâ€–â‰ 0normsubscriptğ†ğ‘–0\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|\neq 0âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰  0 the optimal solution to the optimization problem

argâ¡minğš«âˆˆâ„›dâˆ’ğ‘®iâ‹…ğš«is. t.â€–ğš«iâ€–2â‰¤Î³,â€–ğš«i+ğ‘«iâ€–=1,ğš«superscriptâ„›ğ‘‘â‹…subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğš«ğ‘–missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressions. t.superscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2ğ›¾missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–1missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression\begin{array}[]{ll@{}ll}\underset{{\bm{\Delta}}\in\mathcal{R}^{d}}{\arg\min}&-% {\bm{G}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\\[10.0pt] \textnormal{s. t.}&\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|^{2}\leq\gamma,\\ &\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}+{\bm{D}}_{i}\|=1,\end{array}start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL start_UNDERACCENT bold_Î” âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_arg roman_min end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL - bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL s. t. end_CELL start_CELL âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Î³ , end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 1 , end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

is

ğš«iÎ³={ğ‘®iâ€–ğ‘®iâ€–âˆ’ğ‘«i,ifâ¢cosâ¡Î¸iâ‰¥1âˆ’Î³2Î³â¢(4âˆ’Î³)â¢(ğ‘®iâˆ’(ğ‘«iâ‹…ğ‘®i)â¢ğ‘«i)2â¢â€–ğ‘®iâˆ’(ğ‘«iâ‹…ğ‘®i)â¢ğ‘«iâ€–âˆ’Î³2â¢ğ‘«i,otherwise.superscriptsubscriptğš«ğ‘–ğ›¾casessubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–ifsubscriptğœƒğ‘–1ğ›¾2ğ›¾4ğ›¾subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–â‹…subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–2normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–â‹…subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–ğ›¾2subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–otherwise.{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}^{\gamma}=\begin{cases*}\frac{{\bm{G}}_{i}}{\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|}% -{\bm{D}}_{i},&$\textnormal{if}\;\cos\theta_{i}\geq 1-\frac{\gamma}{2}$\\ \frac{\sqrt{\gamma(4-\gamma)}({\bm{G}}_{i}-({\bm{D}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{G}}_{i}){\bm% {D}}_{i})}{2\|{\bm{G}}_{i}-({\bm{D}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{G}}_{i}){\bm{D}}_{i}\|}-% \frac{\gamma}{2}{\bm{D}}_{i},&{otherwise.}\end{cases*}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î³ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG - bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL if roman_cos italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_Î³ ( 4 - italic_Î³ ) end_ARG ( bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL otherwise. end_CELL end_ROW

For simplicity of notation, we denote by ğ’iâˆˆâ„›dsubscriptğ’ğ‘–superscriptâ„›ğ‘‘{\bm{Z}}_{i}\in\mathcal{R}^{d}bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the vector

ğ’i=ğ‘®iâˆ’(ğ‘«iâ‹…ğ‘®i)â¢ğ‘«iâ€–ğ‘®iâˆ’(ğ‘«iâ‹…ğ‘®i)â¢ğ‘«iâ€–.subscriptğ’ğ‘–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–â‹…subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–â‹…subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–{\bm{Z}}_{i}=\frac{{\bm{G}}_{i}-({\bm{D}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{G}}_{i}){\bm{D}}_{i}}{% \|{\bm{G}}_{i}-({\bm{D}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{G}}_{i}){\bm{D}}_{i}\|}.bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG .

Lemma 3.

Thus, for the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th query and the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th data record, iâˆˆ[nV]ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰i\in[n_{V}]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], jâˆˆ[n]âˆ–YiVğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‰j\in[n]\setminus Y_{i}^{V}italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_n ] âˆ– italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we can use Eq.Â 9 together with Eq.Â 8 to obtain a set Ii,jâŠ†(0,4)subscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘—04I_{i,j}\subseteq{(0,4)}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† ( 0 , 4 ) such that Eq.Â 7 holds if and only if Î³âˆˆIi,jğ›¾subscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘—\gamma\in I_{i,j}italic_Î³ âˆˆ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Moreover, Ii,jsubscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘—I_{i,j}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will consist of at most 3 intervals in âŠ†(0,4)absent04\subseteq{(0,4)}âŠ† ( 0 , 4 ). Let Ii=âˆ©jâˆˆ[n]â‰ YiVIi,jsubscriptğ¼ğ‘–subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‰subscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘—I_{i}=\cap_{j\in[n]\neq Y_{i}^{V}}I_{i,j}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_n ] â‰  italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and note that the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th query will be answered accurately if and only if Î³âˆˆIiğ›¾subscriptğ¼ğ‘–\gamma\in I_{i}italic_Î³ âˆˆ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Finally, Î³âˆ—=argâ¡maxÎ³â¢âˆ‘iâˆˆ[nV]ğ•€â¢[Î³âˆˆIi]superscriptğ›¾subscriptğ›¾subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰ğ•€delimited-[]ğ›¾subscriptğ¼ğ‘–\gamma^{*}=\arg\max_{\gamma}\sum_{i\in[n_{V}]}\mathds{I}[\gamma\in I_{i}]italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_I [ italic_Î³ âˆˆ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] is an optimal solution to the MAxSS problem.

Now whenever â€–ğ‘®jâ€–=0normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘—0\|{\bm{G}}_{j}\|=0âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 0 for any jâˆˆ[n]ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘›j\in[n]italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_n ], Eq.Â 7 changes since we need to also consider ğš«YiVÎ³=0superscriptsubscriptğš«superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ›¾0{\bm{\Delta}}_{Y_{i}^{V}}^{\gamma}=0bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î³ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0, ğš«jÎ³=0superscriptsubscriptğš«ğ‘—ğ›¾0{\bm{\Delta}}_{j}^{\gamma}=0bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î³ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 or both. Each case leads to a similar set of inequalities to Eq.Â 8, which are similarly solved using LemmÂ 3. Moreover, we calculate validation accuracy separately for when Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0italic_Î³ = 0.

\name

-N. \name-N follows the above procedure. It first calculates ğ‘®ğ‘®{\bm{G}}bold_italic_G and ğ’ğ’{\bm{Z}}bold_italic_Z, so that for the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th query, and jğ‘—jitalic_j-th data points, jâ‰ YiVğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‰j\neq Y_{i}^{V}italic_j â‰  italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT applying LemmaÂ 3 to Eq.Â 8 gives Ii,jsubscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘—I_{i,j}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, it computes Iisubscriptğ¼ğ‘–I_{i}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by a single pass over Ii,jsubscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘—I_{i,j}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values, and finally finds a Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ value that intersects most Iisubscriptğ¼ğ‘–I_{i}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s by sorting their beginning and end and iteration through the list.

Time Complexity. Calculating ğ‘®ğ‘®{\bm{G}}bold_italic_G takes time Oâ¢(dâ¢nT)ğ‘‚ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡O(dn_{T})italic_O ( italic_d italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and ğ’ğ’{\bm{Z}}bold_italic_Z takes Oâ¢(dâ¢n)ğ‘‚ğ‘‘ğ‘›O(dn)italic_O ( italic_d italic_n ). Then, for the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th query, it finds Iisubscriptğ¼ğ‘–I_{i}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which takes Oâ¢(nâ¢d)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘‘O(nd)italic_O ( italic_n italic_d ), since each Ii,jsubscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘—I_{i,j}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT only contains a constant number of intervals and can be computed in Oâ¢(d)ğ‘‚ğ‘‘O(d)italic_O ( italic_d ). Finally, finding Î³âˆ—superscriptğ›¾\gamma^{*}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that intersects the most intervals, can be done in Oâ¢(nVâ¢logâ¡nV)ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰O(n_{V}\log n_{V})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Thus, in total, \name-N takes total of Oâ¢(nVâ¢(nâ¢d+logâ¡nV)+nTâ¢d)ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡ğ‘‘O(n_{V}(nd+\log n_{V})+n_{T}d)italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_n italic_d + roman_log italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ).

B.4 Proof of Technical Lemmas

B.4.1 Proof of LemmaÂ 1

If Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0italic_Î³ = 0 the only feasible, and therefore optimal, solution is ğš«=0ğš«0{\bm{\Delta}}=\textbf{0}bold_Î” = 0. Next, consider Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0italic_Î³ > 0. Observe that the optimization problem is convex, so we find ğš«isubscriptğš«ğ‘–{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values that satisfy the KKT conditions which, since the Slaterâ€™s condition holds whenever Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0italic_Î³ > 0, provide necessary and sufficient conditions for optimality.

We have that the Lagrangian is

Lâ¢(ğš«i,Î¼,Î»)=âˆ’ğ‘®iâ‹…ğ‘«i+12â¢Î¼â¢(â€–ğš«iâ€–2âˆ’Î³2),ğ¿subscriptğš«ğ‘–ğœ‡ğœ†â‹…subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–12ğœ‡superscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2superscriptğ›¾2L({\bm{\Delta}}_{i},\mu,\lambda)=-{\bm{G}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i}+\frac{1}{2}\mu% (\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|^{2}-\gamma^{2}),italic_L ( bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ , italic_Î» ) = - bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_Î¼ ( âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ,

so that the KKT conditions are

âˆ’ğ‘®i+Î¼â¢ğš«isubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–ğœ‡subscriptğš«ğ‘–\displaystyle-{\bm{G}}_{i}+\mu{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}- bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î¼ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =0,absent0\displaystyle=\textbf{0},= 0 , (10)
Î¼â¢(â€–ğš«iâ€–2âˆ’Î³2)ğœ‡superscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2superscriptğ›¾2\displaystyle\mu(\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|^{2}-\gamma^{2})italic_Î¼ ( âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) =0,absent0\displaystyle=0,= 0 , (11)
Î¼â‰¥0.ğœ‡0\displaystyle\mu\geq 0.italic_Î¼ â‰¥ 0 . (12)

If Î¼=0ğœ‡0\mu=0italic_Î¼ = 0, we must have â€–ğ‘®iâ€–=0normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–0\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|=0âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 0, which is a contradiction. Thus, Î¼>0ğœ‡0\mu>0italic_Î¼ > 0, and

â€–ğš«iâ€–2âˆ’Î³2=0.superscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2superscriptğ›¾20\displaystyle\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|^{2}-\gamma^{2}=0.âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 . (13)

From Eq.Â 10,

ğš«i=ğ‘®iÎ¼subscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–ğœ‡\displaystyle{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}=\frac{{\bm{G}}_{i}}{\mu}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î¼ end_ARG (14)

Substituting this into Eq.Â 13, and since Î¼>0ğœ‡0\mu>0italic_Î¼ > 0, we have

Î¼=â€–ğ‘®iâ€–Î³,ğœ‡normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–ğ›¾\mu=\frac{\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|}{\gamma},italic_Î¼ = divide start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG ,

and substituting back into Eq.Â 14, we have

ğš«i=Î³â¢ğ‘®iâ€–ğ‘®iâ€–.subscriptğš«ğ‘–ğ›¾subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}=\gamma\frac{{\bm{G}}_{i}}{\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|}.bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î³ divide start_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG .

B.4.2 Proof of LemmaÂ 2

We replace â€–ğš«i+ğ‘«iâ€–=1normsubscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–1\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}+{\bm{D}}_{i}\|=1âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 1 with â€–ğš«i+ğ‘«iâ€–â‰¤1normsubscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–1\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}+{\bm{D}}_{i}\|\leq 1âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ 1 so that the optimization is over a convex set, and solve the problem with â€–ğš«i+ğ‘«iâ€–â‰¤1normsubscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–1\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}+{\bm{D}}_{i}\|\leq 1âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ 1 constraint. As we will see, the only solution to the problem will have â€–ğš«i+ğ‘«iâ€–=1normsubscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–1\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}+{\bm{D}}_{i}\|=1âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 1, implying that it is the optimal solution to the original problem as well. Thus, consider the convex problem with â€–ğš«i+ğ‘«iâ€–â‰¤1normsubscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–1\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}+{\bm{D}}_{i}\|\leq 1âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ 1 constraint, or equivalantly â€–ğš«i+ğ‘«iâ€–2â‰¤1superscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–21\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}+{\bm{D}}_{i}\|^{2}\leq 1âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 1.

We find ğš«isubscriptğš«ğ‘–{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values that satisfy the KKT conditions, which, since the Slaterâ€™s condition holds whenever Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0italic_Î³ > 0, provide necessary and sufficient conditions for optimality.

We have that the Lagrangian is

Lâ¢(ğš«i,Î¼,Î»)=âˆ’ğ‘®iâ‹…ğ‘«i+12â¢Î¼â¢(â€–ğš«iâ€–2âˆ’Î³)+12â¢Î»â¢(â€–ğš«iâ€–2+2â¢ğš«iâ‹…ğ‘«i),ğ¿subscriptğš«ğ‘–ğœ‡ğœ†â‹…subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–12ğœ‡superscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2ğ›¾12ğœ†superscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2â‹…2subscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–L({\bm{\Delta}}_{i},\mu,\lambda)=-{\bm{G}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i}+\frac{1}{2}\mu% (\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|^{2}-\gamma)+\frac{1}{2}\lambda(\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|^{2% }+2{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i}),italic_L ( bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î¼ , italic_Î» ) = - bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_Î¼ ( âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î³ ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_Î» ( âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

so that the KKT conditions are

âˆ’ğ‘®i+Î¼â¢ğš«i+Î»â¢ğš«i+Î»â¢ğ‘«isubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–ğœ‡subscriptğš«ğ‘–ğœ†subscriptğš«ğ‘–ğœ†subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–\displaystyle-{\bm{G}}_{i}+\mu{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}+\lambda{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}+% \lambda{\bm{D}}_{i}- bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î¼ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î» bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î» bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =0,absent0\displaystyle=\textbf{0},= 0 , (15)
Î»â¢(â€–ğš«iâ€–2+2â¢ğš«iâ‹…ğ‘«i)ğœ†superscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2â‹…2subscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–\displaystyle\lambda(\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|^{2}+2{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}% _{i})italic_Î» ( âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =0,absent0\displaystyle=0,= 0 , (16)
Î¼â¢(â€–ğš«iâ€–2âˆ’Î³)ğœ‡superscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2ğ›¾\displaystyle\mu(\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|^{2}-\gamma)italic_Î¼ ( âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î³ ) =0,absent0\displaystyle=0,= 0 , (17)
â€–ğš«iâ€–2superscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2\displaystyle\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|^{2}âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤Î³,absentğ›¾\displaystyle\leq\gamma,â‰¤ italic_Î³ , (18)
â€–ğš«iâ€–2+2â¢ğš«iâ‹…ğ‘«isuperscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2â‹…2subscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–\displaystyle\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|^{2}+2{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i}âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤0,absent0\displaystyle\leq 0,â‰¤ 0 , (19)
Î¼,Î»ğœ‡ğœ†\displaystyle\mu,\lambdaitalic_Î¼ , italic_Î» â‰¥0,absent0\displaystyle\geq 0,â‰¥ 0 , (20)

where Eq.Â 15 is obtained by setting the gradient of the Lagrangian to zero, and Eq.Â 19 and Â 16 are obtained by substituting

â€–ğ‘«i+ğš«iâ€–2=â€–ğ‘«iâ€–2+â€–ğš«iâ€–2+2â¢ğš«iâ‹…ğ‘«i=1+â€–ğš«iâ€–2+2â¢ğš«iâ‹…ğ‘«i,superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğš«ğ‘–2superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–2superscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2â‹…2subscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–1superscriptnormsubscriptğš«ğ‘–2â‹…2subscriptğš«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–\|{\bm{D}}_{i}+{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|^{2}=\|{\bm{D}}_{i}\|^{2}+\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i% }\|^{2}+2{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i}=1+\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|^{2}+2{\bm{% \Delta}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i},âˆ¥ bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ¥ bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 + âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

since â€–ğš«iâ€–=1normsubscriptğš«ğ‘–1\|{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}\|=1âˆ¥ bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 1.

To find the points satisfying all Eq.Â 15-20, we consider 4 setting depending on whether Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0italic_Î» = 0 or Î¼=0ğœ‡0\mu=0italic_Î¼ = 0 or not.

Case 1, Î»=0,Î¼=0formulae-sequenceğœ†0ğœ‡0\lambda=0,\mu=0italic_Î» = 0 , italic_Î¼ = 0. Substituting Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0italic_Î» = 0 and Î¼=0ğœ‡0\mu=0italic_Î¼ = 0 in Eq.Â 15, we have ğ‘®i=ğŸsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–0{\bm{G}}_{i}=\mathbf{0}bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_0. Thus, no solution with Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0italic_Î» = 0 and Î¼=0ğœ‡0\mu=0italic_Î¼ = 0 exists since ğ‘®iâ‰ ğŸsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–0{\bm{G}}_{i}\neq\mathbf{0}bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  bold_0.

Case 2, Î»=0,Î¼>0formulae-sequenceğœ†0ğœ‡0\lambda=0,\mu>0italic_Î» = 0 , italic_Î¼ > 0. Having Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0italic_Î» = 0 and Î¼>0ğœ‡0\mu>0italic_Î¼ > 0, we have from Eq.Â 15

ğš«i=1Î¼â¢ğ‘®i,subscriptğš«ğ‘–1ğœ‡subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}=\frac{1}{\mu}{\bm{G}}_{i},bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î¼ end_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

substituting which into Eq.Â 17 with Î¼>0ğœ‡0\mu>0italic_Î¼ > 0 w have

1Î¼2â¢â€–ğ‘®iâ€–2=Î³,1superscriptğœ‡2superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–2ğ›¾\displaystyle\frac{1}{\mu^{2}}\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|^{2}=\gamma,divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Î³ ,
Î¼=â€–ğ‘®iâ€–Î³,ğœ‡normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–ğ›¾\displaystyle\mu=\frac{\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|}{\sqrt{\gamma}},italic_Î¼ = divide start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG end_ARG ,

and therefore ğš«i=Î³â¢ğ‘®iâ€–ğ‘®iâ€–subscriptğš«ğ‘–ğ›¾subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}=\sqrt{\gamma}\frac{{\bm{G}}_{i}}{\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|}bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG divide start_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG (KKT conditions become similar to the ones in TheoremÂ 2). and therefore

satisfy all KKT conditions whenever cosâ¡Î¸iâ‰¥1âˆ’Î³2subscriptğœƒğ‘–1ğ›¾2\cos\theta_{i}\geq 1-\frac{\gamma}{2}roman_cos italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG.

So

Î³4â¢(â€–ğ‘®iâ€–2âˆ’Î»2âˆ’2â¢Î»â¢ğ‘®iâ‹…ğ‘«i)=Î»2+(ğ‘®iâ‹…ğ‘«i)2âˆ’2â¢Î»â¢ğ‘®iâ‹…ğ‘«i.ğ›¾4superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–2superscriptğœ†2â‹…2ğœ†subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–superscriptğœ†2superscriptâ‹…subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–2â‹…2ğœ†subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–\frac{\gamma}{4}(\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|^{2}-\lambda^{2}-2\lambda{\bm{G}}_{i}\cdot{% \bm{D}}_{i})=\lambda^{2}+({\bm{G}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i})^{2}-2\lambda{\bm{G}}_% {i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{i}.divide start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ( âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_Î» bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_Î» bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

where we have used the fact that (ğ‘«iâ‹…ğ‘®i)2=â€–ğ‘®iâ€–2â¢cos2â¡Î¸isuperscriptâ‹…subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–2superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–2superscript2subscriptğœƒğ‘–({\bm{D}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{G}}_{i})^{2}=\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|^{2}\cos^{2}\theta_{i}( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_cos start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Î»=ğ‘«iâ‹…ğ‘®iÂ±â€–ğ‘®iâ€–â¢sinâ¡Î¸iâ¢Î³4âˆ’Î³.ğœ†plus-or-minusâ‹…subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ›¾4ğ›¾\displaystyle\lambda={\bm{D}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{G}}_{i}\pm\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|\sin% \theta_{i}\sqrt{\frac{\gamma}{4-\gamma}}.italic_Î» = bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â± âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ roman_sin italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG 4 - italic_Î³ end_ARG end_ARG . Note that we must also have Î¼>0ğœ‡0\mu>0italic_Î¼ > 0, so substituting Eq.Â 24 into Eq.Â 22 and rearranging we must have

Â±â€–ğ‘®iâ€–â¢sinâ¡Î¸iâ¢Î³4âˆ’Î³â¢(2Î³âˆ’1)âˆ’ğ‘«iâ‹…ğ‘®i>plus-or-minusnormsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ›¾4ğ›¾2ğ›¾1â‹…subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–absent\displaystyle\pm\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|\sin\theta_{i}\sqrt{\frac{\gamma}{4-\gamma}}(% \frac{2}{\gamma}-1)-{\bm{D}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{G}}_{i}>Â± âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ roman_sin italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG 4 - italic_Î³ end_ARG end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG - 1 ) - bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > â€‰0,â€‰0\displaystyle\,0,0 ,
Â±sinâ¡Î¸iâ¢Î³4âˆ’Î³â¢(2Î³âˆ’1)>plus-or-minussubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ›¾4ğ›¾2ğ›¾1absent\displaystyle\pm\sin\theta_{i}\sqrt{\frac{\gamma}{4-\gamma}}(\frac{2}{\gamma}-% 1)>Â± roman_sin italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG 4 - italic_Î³ end_ARG end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG - 1 ) > cosâ¡Î¸i.subscriptğœƒğ‘–\displaystyle\cos\theta_{i}.roman_cos italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (25)

Observe that, for Î¸iâˆˆ[0,Ï€2]subscriptğœƒğ‘–0ğœ‹2\theta_{i}\in[0,\frac{\pi}{2}]italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ 0 , divide start_ARG italic_Ï€ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ], both sinâ¡Î¸isubscriptğœƒğ‘–\sin\theta_{i}roman_sin italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and cosâ¡Î¸isubscriptğœƒğ‘–\cos\theta_{i}roman_cos italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are non-negative, so that when Î³<2ğ›¾2\gamma<2italic_Î³ < 2 only the positive branch is able to satisfy Eq.Â 25. (26)

Note that

To summarize, taking the positive branch in Eq.Â 24, we showed that

satisfy the KKT conditions whenever

Finally, observe that â€–ğ‘®iâˆ’(ğ‘«iâ‹…ğ‘®i)â¢ğ‘«iâ€–=â€–ğ‘®iâ€–â¢sinâ¡Î¸inormsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–â‹…subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘–\|{\bm{G}}_{i}-({\bm{D}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{G}}_{i}){\bm{D}}_{i}\|=\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|% \sin\theta_{i}âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ roman_sin italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. âˆ

B.4.3 Proof of LemmaÂ 3

We first find Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ values where fâ¢(Î³)=0ğ‘“ğ›¾0f(\gamma)=0italic_f ( italic_Î³ ) = 0. Observe that

aâ¢Î³â¢(4âˆ’Î³)+bâ¢Î³+c=0â‡’a2â¢Î³â¢(4âˆ’Î³)âˆ’(bâ¢Î³+c)2=0,ğ‘ğ›¾4ğ›¾ğ‘ğ›¾ğ‘0â‡’superscriptğ‘2ğ›¾4ğ›¾superscriptğ‘ğ›¾ğ‘20a\sqrt{\gamma(4-\gamma)}+b\gamma+c=0\Rightarrow a^{2}\gamma(4-\gamma)-(b\gamma% +c)^{2}=0,italic_a square-root start_ARG italic_Î³ ( 4 - italic_Î³ ) end_ARG + italic_b italic_Î³ + italic_c = 0 â‡’ italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î³ ( 4 - italic_Î³ ) - ( italic_b italic_Î³ + italic_c ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 ,

so that a2â¢Î³â¢(4âˆ’Î³)âˆ’(bâ¢Î³+c)2=0superscriptğ‘2ğ›¾4ğ›¾superscriptğ‘ğ›¾ğ‘20a^{2}\gamma(4-\gamma)-(b\gamma+c)^{2}=0italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î³ ( 4 - italic_Î³ ) - ( italic_b italic_Î³ + italic_c ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 is necessary for fâ¢(Î³)=0ğ‘“ğ›¾0f(\gamma)=0italic_f ( italic_Î³ ) = 0. Moreover solving the quadratic inequality, a2â¢Î³â¢(4âˆ’Î³)âˆ’(bâ¢Î³+c)2=0superscriptğ‘2ğ›¾4ğ›¾superscriptğ‘ğ›¾ğ‘20a^{2}\gamma(4-\gamma)-(b\gamma+c)^{2}=0italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î³ ( 4 - italic_Î³ ) - ( italic_b italic_Î³ + italic_c ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 iff Î³âˆˆ{Î³0,Î³1}ğ›¾subscriptğ›¾0subscriptğ›¾1\gamma\in\{\gamma_{0},\gamma_{1}\}italic_Î³ âˆˆ { italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } where

Î³0=2â¢a2âˆ’bâ¢câˆ’aâ¢Î´a2+b2,Î³1=2â¢a2âˆ’bâ¢c+aâ¢Î´a2+b2,forÂ â¢Î´=4â¢a2âˆ’4â¢bâ¢câˆ’a2â¢c2.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ›¾02superscriptğ‘2ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ›¿superscriptğ‘2superscriptğ‘2formulae-sequencesubscriptğ›¾12superscriptğ‘2ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ›¿superscriptğ‘2superscriptğ‘2forÂ ğ›¿4superscriptğ‘24ğ‘ğ‘superscriptğ‘2superscriptğ‘2\gamma_{0}=\frac{2a^{2}-bc-a\sqrt{\delta}}{a^{2}+b^{2}},\;\gamma_{1}=\frac{2a^% {2}-bc+a\sqrt{\delta}}{a^{2}+b^{2}},\;\textnormal{for }\delta=4a^{2}-4bc-a^{2}% c^{2}.italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 2 italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_b italic_c - italic_a square-root start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 2 italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_b italic_c + italic_a square-root start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , for italic_Î´ = 4 italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 italic_b italic_c - italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Thus, Î³âˆˆ{Î³0,Î³1}ğ›¾subscriptğ›¾0subscriptğ›¾1\gamma\in\{\gamma_{0},\gamma_{1}\}italic_Î³ âˆˆ { italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is necessary for fâ¢(Î³)=0ğ‘“ğ›¾0f(\gamma)=0italic_f ( italic_Î³ ) = 0, which proves the first part of the lemma.

The proof of the rest of the lemma uses the above, the fact that fğ‘“fitalic_f is continuous, in addition to the following facts:

c>0â‡’fâ¢(0)>0,c<0â‡’fâ¢(0)<0formulae-sequenceğ‘0â‡’ğ‘“00ğ‘0â‡’ğ‘“00\displaystyle c>0\Rightarrow f(0)>0,\;c<0\Rightarrow f(0)<0italic_c > 0 â‡’ italic_f ( 0 ) > 0 , italic_c < 0 â‡’ italic_f ( 0 ) < 0 (28)
c=0,b>0â‡’fâ¢(4)>0,c=0,b<0â‡’fâ¢(4)<0formulae-sequenceformulae-sequenceğ‘0ğ‘0â‡’ğ‘“40formulae-sequenceğ‘0ğ‘0â‡’ğ‘“40\displaystyle c=0,b>0\Rightarrow f(4)>0,\;c=0,b<0\Rightarrow f(4)<0italic_c = 0 , italic_b > 0 â‡’ italic_f ( 4 ) > 0 , italic_c = 0 , italic_b < 0 â‡’ italic_f ( 4 ) < 0 (29)
fâ¢Â has at most 1 local extrema, which is a maximum ifÂ â¢a>0â¢Â and a minimum ifÂ â¢a<0ğ‘“Â has at most 1 local extrema, which is a maximum ifÂ ğ‘0Â and a minimum ifÂ ğ‘0\displaystyle f\text{ has at most 1 local extrema, which is a maximum if }a>0% \text{ and a minimum if }a<0italic_f has at most 1 local extrema, which is a maximum if italic_a > 0 and a minimum if italic_a < 0 (30)

If there are zero roots, fâ¢(Î³)>0ğ‘“ğ›¾0f(\gamma)>0italic_f ( italic_Î³ ) > 0 either for all of (0,4)04(0,4)( 0 , 4 ) or none of it, which can be determined by checking the function value at 0 or 4 using Eq.Â 28 and 29 if câ‰ 0ğ‘0c\neq 0italic_c â‰  0 or bâ‰ 0ğ‘0b\neq 0italic_b â‰  0. If c=b=0ğ‘ğ‘0c=b=0italic_c = italic_b = 0, then we can solve fâ¢(Î³)>0ğ‘“ğ›¾0f(\gamma)>0italic_f ( italic_Î³ ) > 0 based on whether the function has a minimum or maximum using Eq.Â 30, or is a constant when a=0ğ‘0a=0italic_a = 0.

If there is one root, Î³0subscriptğ›¾0\gamma_{0}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then fâ¢(Î³)ğ‘“ğ›¾f(\gamma)italic_f ( italic_Î³ ) is either positive after Î³0subscriptğ›¾0\gamma_{0}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or before it. If câ‰ 0ğ‘0c\neq 0italic_c â‰  0, we can find this by checking fâ¢(0)ğ‘“0f(0)italic_f ( 0 ) using Eq.Â 28. If c=0ğ‘0c=0italic_c = 0, then fâ¢(Î³)ğ‘“ğ›¾f(\gamma)italic_f ( italic_Î³ ) has two roots, at 00 and Î³0subscriptğ›¾0\gamma_{0}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and fâ¢(Î³)>0ğ‘“ğ›¾0f(\gamma)>0italic_f ( italic_Î³ ) > 0 can be determined based on whether the function has a minimum or maximum using Eq.Â 30. Both cğ‘citalic_c and ağ‘aitalic_a cannot be zero, because the function bâ¢Î³ğ‘ğ›¾b\gammaitalic_b italic_Î³ cannot be zero both at Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0italic_Î³ = 0 and Î³=Î³0ğ›¾subscriptğ›¾0\gamma=\gamma_{0}italic_Î³ = italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for Î³0â‰ 0subscriptğ›¾00\gamma_{0}\neq 0italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  0.

If there are two roots, then fâ¢(Î³)>0ğ‘“ğ›¾0f(\gamma)>0italic_f ( italic_Î³ ) > 0 either between the two roots, or outside the interval between the two roots, which can be checked based on fâ¢(0)ğ‘“0f(0)italic_f ( 0 ) using EqÂ 28. cğ‘citalic_c cannot be zero because fâ¢(Î³)ğ‘“ğ›¾f(\gamma)italic_f ( italic_Î³ ) cannot be zero at Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0italic_Î³ = 0, Î³=Î³0ğ›¾subscriptğ›¾0\gamma=\gamma_{0}italic_Î³ = italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Î³=Î³1ğ›¾subscriptğ›¾1\gamma=\gamma_{1}italic_Î³ = italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for 3 distinct values fo 0,Î³0,Î³10subscriptğ›¾0subscriptğ›¾10,\gamma_{0},\gamma_{1}0 , italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. âˆ

Appendix C Iterative \name Variants

In the main body of the paper, we presented two \name variants, \name-M and \name-N. this section presents other practical extensions that are more flexible in their optimization approach but do not provide closed-form optimal solutions.

Specifically, the \name variants discussed in the paper can be difficult to implement (especially \name-N) and are not flexible, e.g., considering other accuracy metrics or constraints requires a new theoretical study. Here, we discuss simple \name variants that use gradient descent to optimize MaxS-EFT (e.g., to solve the inner optimization in BiMax-M) and hyperparameter tuning to optimize MaxA-EFT (e.g., to solve the outer optimization in BiMax-M). This approaches can be less efficient and suboptimal, but can still provide accurate solutions, and are simple and flexible. In such \name variants, the learning rate and number of iterations act as knobs constraining how much the embeddings change.

\name

-IM. First, note that MaxS-EFT is equivalent to minimizing the following loss

â„’=âˆ’âˆ‘iâˆˆ[nT]ğ‘¸iâ‹…(ğ‘«Yi+ğš«Yi).â„’subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡â‹…subscriptğ‘¸ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–subscriptğš«subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–\displaystyle\mathcal{L}=-\sum_{i\in[n_{T}]}{\bm{Q}}_{i}\cdot({\bm{D}}_{Y_{i}}% +{\bm{\Delta}}_{Y_{i}}).caligraphic_L = - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (31)
\name

-IM performs gradient descent on loss in Eq.Â 31 with learning rate Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± for tğ‘¡titalic_t iterations (Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± and tğ‘¡titalic_t determined through hyperparameter tuning to maximize validation accuracy) with normalized gradients:

ğš«(0)â†ğŸ,ğš«(t)â†ğš«(tâˆ’1)âˆ’Î±â¢âˆ‡ğš«â„’â€–âˆ‡ğš«â„’â€–.formulae-sequenceâ†superscriptğš«00â†superscriptğš«ğ‘¡superscriptğš«ğ‘¡1ğ›¼subscriptâˆ‡ğš«â„’normsubscriptâˆ‡ğš«â„’\displaystyle{\bm{\Delta}}^{(0)}\leftarrow\mathbf{0},\;{\bm{\Delta}}^{(t)}% \leftarrow{\bm{\Delta}}^{(t-1)}-\alpha\frac{\nabla_{{\bm{\Delta}}}\mathcal{L}}% {\|\nabla_{{\bm{\Delta}}}\mathcal{L}\|}.bold_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â† bold_0 , bold_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â† bold_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î± divide start_ARG âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_Î” end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_Î” end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L âˆ¥ end_ARG .
Lemma 4.
\name

-IM finds a solution equal to \name-IM, and thus optimally solves BiMax-M, whenever Î±â¢t=Î³âˆ—ğ›¼ğ‘¡superscriptğ›¾\alpha t=\gamma^{*}italic_Î± italic_t = italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where Î³âˆ—superscriptğ›¾\gamma^{*}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the optimal Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ value found by \name-M.

Proof. Observe that ğ‘®i=âˆ’âˆ‡ğš«iâ„’subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğš«ğ‘–â„’{\bm{G}}_{i}=-\nabla_{{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}}\mathcal{L}bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L, and therefore the gradient remains constant through optimization. Thus, after tğ‘¡titalic_t iterations, we have

ğš«i(t)=Î±â¢tâ¢ğ•€â¢[ğ‘®iâ‰ 0]â¢ğ‘®iâ€–ğ‘®iâ€–.superscriptsubscriptğš«ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğ‘¡ğ•€delimited-[]subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–0subscriptğ‘®ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘–{\bm{\Delta}}_{i}^{(t)}=\alpha t\mathds{I}[{\bm{G}}_{i}\neq 0]\frac{{\bm{G}}_{% i}}{\|{\bm{G}}_{i}\|}.bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Î± italic_t blackboard_I [ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  0 ] divide start_ARG bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG .

Thus, setting Î³âˆ—=Î±â¢tsuperscriptğ›¾ğ›¼ğ‘¡\gamma^{*}=\alpha titalic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Î± italic_t, we obtain the same results as \name-M.âˆ

The above lemma implies using gradient descent with suitable Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± and tğ‘¡titalic_t can also provide accurate solutions, but at the cost of efficiency due to iterative updates and hyperparameter tuning (instead of using the closed-form solutions), and the added challenge of finding suitable Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± and tğ‘¡titalic_t. Appx.Â E.5 presents an experimental study of these trade-offs.

\name

-IN. Another alternative is \name-IN, an iteratively normalized \name variant. \name-IN is similar to \name-IM but normalizes the embeddings after every update:

ğ‘«i(0)â†ğ‘«i,ğ‘«i(t)â†ğ‘«i(tâˆ’1)+Î±â¢âˆ‡ğš«â„’â€–âˆ‡ğš«â„’â€–â€–ğ‘«i(tâˆ’1)+Î±â¢âˆ‡ğš«â„’â€–âˆ‡ğš«â„’â€–â€–âˆ€iâˆˆ[n].formulae-sequenceâ†subscriptsuperscriptğ‘«0ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–formulae-sequenceâ†subscriptsuperscriptğ‘«ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘«ğ‘¡1ğ‘–ğ›¼subscriptâˆ‡ğš«â„’normsubscriptâˆ‡ğš«â„’normsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘«ğ‘¡1ğ‘–ğ›¼subscriptâˆ‡ğš«â„’normsubscriptâˆ‡ğš«â„’for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›{\bm{D}}^{(0)}_{i}\leftarrow{\bm{D}}_{i},\quad{\bm{D}}^{(t)}_{i}\leftarrow% \frac{{\bm{D}}^{(t-1)}_{i}+\alpha\frac{\nabla_{{\bm{\Delta}}}\mathcal{L}}{\|% \nabla_{{\bm{\Delta}}}\mathcal{L}\|}}{\|{\bm{D}}^{(t-1)}_{i}+\alpha\frac{% \nabla_{{\bm{\Delta}}}\mathcal{L}}{\|\nabla_{{\bm{\Delta}}}\mathcal{L}\|}\|}% \quad\forall i\in[n].bold_italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â† bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â† divide start_ARG bold_italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î± divide start_ARG âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_Î” end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_Î” end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L âˆ¥ end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î± divide start_ARG âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_Î” end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_Î” end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L âˆ¥ end_ARG âˆ¥ end_ARG âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] .
\name

-IN ensure the fine-tuned embeddings are normalized similar to \name-N. Although, there is no theoretical equivalency between the solutions of \name-IN and \name-N, we observed similar accuracy in practice. Meanwhile, \name-IN is less efficient but simpler to implement.

Appendix D Multi-Label Formulation

In the main body of the paper, we provided fine-tuning solutions assuming each query has a single ground-truth answer. Here, we discuss how our results can be extended to a multi-label setting. We first formalize the problem setting with multiple labels and then discuss how to extend our results.

Ground-Truth Answers. For a query, ğ’’ğ’’{\bm{q}}bold_italic_q, its ground-truth answer is a ranking of the data records so that the highest-ranked records are the most related to the query. This ranking can be represented using relevance scores, which, for each data record, quantifies how related the record is to the query (relevance score zero means the record is unrelated). The ground-truth ranking can be obtained by sorting the data records based on their relevance scores. More formally, we represent the ground-truth ranking for a query with a ground-truth rank index set, y={y1,â€¦,yp}ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘¦1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘y=\{y_{1},...,y_{p}\}italic_y = { italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and corresponding ground-truth relevance score set r={r1,â€¦,rp}ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1â€¦subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘r=\{r_{1},...,r_{p}\}italic_r = { italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } for some integer pğ‘pitalic_p denoting the number of data records that are related to the query; the remaining records are not relate to the query. This means that record DÂ¯yisubscriptÂ¯ğ·subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\bar{D}_{y_{i}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has relevance risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the query, and any record index not present in yğ‘¦yitalic_y is assumed to have zero relevance score. Thus, sorting the dataset based on rğ‘Ÿritalic_r gives the ground-truth answer to the query. We drop the set rğ‘Ÿritalic_r if |y|=1ğ‘¦1|y|=1| italic_y | = 1, or if r1=â€¦=rp=1subscriptğ‘Ÿ1â€¦subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘1r_{1}=...=r_{p}=1italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = â€¦ = italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1.

Fine-Tuning Query Sets. For fine-tuning, a query set and corresponding ground-truth answers are available, consisting of queries QÂ¯Â¯ğ‘„\bar{Q}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG and ground-truth answer sets Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y, Rğ‘…Ritalic_R, where for the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th query qÂ¯jâˆˆQÂ¯subscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘—Â¯ğ‘„\bar{q}_{j}\in\bar{Q}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG, Yjsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘—Y_{j}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the ground-truth index set and Rjsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘—R_{j}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the ground-truth relevance score set for qÂ¯jsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘—\bar{q}_{j}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We assume this training set is split into two, a training set QÂ¯T,YTsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘„ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡\bar{Q}^{T},Y^{T}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, RTsuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘‡R^{T}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and a validation set QÂ¯V,YV,RVsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘„ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘Œğ‘‰superscriptğ‘…ğ‘‰\bar{Q}^{V},Y^{V},R^{V}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with nTsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡n_{T}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and nVsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰n_{V}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT queries respectively. Similar to single label setting, let ğ‘¸Tâˆˆâ„›nTÃ—dsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘‡superscriptâ„›subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡ğ‘‘{\bm{Q}}^{T}\in\mathcal{R}^{n_{T}\times d}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ‘¸Vâˆˆâ„›nVÃ—dsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘‰superscriptâ„›subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‰ğ‘‘{\bm{Q}}^{V}\in\mathcal{R}^{n_{V}\times d}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be matrices containing embeddings for training and validation queries.

Problem Formulation. Both MaxS-EFT and MaxA-EFT can be modified to utilize multiple labels. For MaxS-EFT we can change the objective to âˆ‘iâˆˆ[nT]âˆ‘jâˆ—âˆˆYiTğ‘¸iTâ‹…(ğ‘«jâˆ—+ğš«jâˆ—)subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‡â‹…subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¸ğ‘‡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«superscriptğ‘—subscriptğš«superscriptğ‘—\sum_{i\in[n_{T}]}\sum_{j^{*}\in Y_{i}^{T}}{\bm{Q}}^{T}_{i}\cdot({\bm{D}}_{j^{% *}}+{\bm{\Delta}}_{j^{*}})âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where summation over YiTsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘‡Y_{i}^{T}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can optionally be weighted by relevance scores. For MaxA-EFT, we can adjust the inequalities in the definition of the correct answer to a query (i.e., Eq.Â 1), so that for a query ğ’’ğ’’{\bm{q}}bold_italic_q with two relevance scores r1subscriptğ‘Ÿ1r_{1}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and r2subscriptğ‘Ÿ2r_{2}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, r1>r2subscriptğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ‘Ÿ2r_{1}>r_{2}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and for R1subscriptğ‘…1R_{1}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and R2subscriptğ‘…2R_{2}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT containing document indexes with r1subscriptğ‘Ÿ1r_{1}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and r2subscriptğ‘Ÿ2r_{2}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT relevance scores, we say ğ’’ğ’’{\bm{q}}bold_italic_q is answered correctly when

ğ’’â‹…(ğ‘«i+ğš«i)>ğ’’â‹…(ğ‘«j+ğš«j),iâˆˆR1,jâˆˆR2.formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ’’subscriptğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptğš«ğ‘–â‹…ğ’’subscriptğ‘«ğ‘—subscriptğš«ğ‘—formulae-sequenceğ‘–subscriptğ‘…1ğ‘—subscriptğ‘…2\displaystyle{\bm{q}}\cdot({\bm{D}}_{i}+{\bm{\Delta}}_{i})>{\bm{q}}\cdot({\bm{% D}}_{j}+{\bm{\Delta}}_{j}),\;i\in R_{1},j\in R_{2}.bold_italic_q â‹… ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > bold_italic_q â‹… ( bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_i âˆˆ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j âˆˆ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (32)
\name

. To solve BiMax-M and BiMax-N, observe that the above modifications cause marginal changes for MaxS-M and MaxS-N, and only require modifying the definition of ğ‘®ğ‘®{\bm{G}}bold_italic_G in the corresponding optimal solutions. However, the solutions to the outer optimization problem in BiMax-M and BiMax-N require further modifications since now a different set of inequalities needs to be solved to find the range of Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ for which a query is answered correctly. However, each inequality is still of the same form as before (compare Eq.Â 32 with Eq.Â 1), and thus, the same methodology applies.

Appendix E Additional Experiments and Details

Here we present additional experimental details and results:

  • â€¢

    Appx.Â E.1 discussed details on the implementation of Adaptor and PTFT, including hyper-parameter tuning, loss, and efficiency considerations.

  • â€¢

    Appx.Â E.2 contains detailed per dataset results summarized in the paperâ€™s main body.

  • â€¢

    Appx.Â E.3 presents experiments on the training processes of Adaptors and PTFT to understand their failure modes.

  • â€¢

    Appx.Â E.4 provides an ablation study of various normalization methods in \name.

  • â€¢

    Appx.Â E.5 provides an experimental comparison between \name-M and its corresponding iterative variant \name-IM.

E.1 Adaptor and PTFT details and hyper-parameter tuning

-L loss. The results presented with -L suffix use a modified version of MNR loss. The MNR loss, for a batch of bğ‘bitalic_b queries, ğ‘¸Bsuperscriptğ‘¸ğµ{\bm{Q}}^{B}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and positive examples (i.e., data records that the correct answer to queries) ğ‘«Bsuperscriptğ‘«ğµ{\bm{D}}^{B}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ğ‘«isubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–{\bm{D}}_{i}bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a positive example for ğ‘¸isubscriptğ‘¸ğ‘–{\bm{Q}}_{i}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any iâˆˆ[b]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘i\in[b]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_b ], treats every other example in the batch as negative examples for ğ‘¸isubscriptğ‘¸ğ‘–{\bm{Q}}_{i}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let ğ’®i,j=ğ‘¸iâ‹…ğ‘«jâ€–ğ‘¸iâ€–â¢â€–ğ‘«iâ€–subscriptğ’®ğ‘–ğ‘—â‹…subscriptğ‘¸ğ‘–subscriptğ‘«ğ‘—normsubscriptğ‘¸ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘«ğ‘–\mathcal{S}_{i,j}=\frac{{\bm{Q}}_{i}\cdot{\bm{D}}_{j}}{\|{\bm{Q}}_{i}\|\|{\bm{% D}}_{i}\|}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ âˆ¥ bold_italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG for any i,jâˆˆ[b]ğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘i,j\in[b]italic_i , italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_b ]. Then, MNR loss minimizes

â„’Mâ¢Nâ¢R=âˆ’âˆ‘iâˆˆ[b]logâ¡eÏ„â¢ğ’®i,iâˆ‘jâˆˆ[b]eÏ„â¢ğ’®i,j,subscriptâ„’ğ‘€ğ‘ğ‘…subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘superscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–ğ‘–subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘superscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathcal{L}_{MNR}=-\sum_{i\in[b]}\log\frac{e^{\tau\mathcal{S}_{i,i}}}{\sum_{j% \in[b]}e^{\tau\mathcal{S}_{i,j}}},caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_N italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_b ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_b ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ,

for some temperature parameter Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. Our modified loss, for the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th query, ignores samples, jğ‘—jitalic_j, for which ğ’®i,j<Î·subscriptğ’®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ‚\mathcal{S}_{i,j}<\etacaligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_Î· for some threshold Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·:

â„’â€²=âˆ’âˆ‘iâˆˆ[b]logâ¡ğ•€â¢[ğ’®i,iâ‰¥Î·]â¢eÏ„â¢ğ’®i,iâˆ‘jâˆˆ[b]ğ•€â¢[ğ’®i,jâ‰¥Î·]â¢eÏ„â¢ğ’®i,j.superscriptâ„’â€²subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘ğ•€delimited-[]subscriptğ’®ğ‘–ğ‘–ğœ‚superscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–ğ‘–subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘ğ•€delimited-[]subscriptğ’®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ‚superscriptğ‘’ğœsubscriptğ’®ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathcal{L^{\prime}}=-\sum_{i\in[b]}\log\frac{\mathds{I}[\mathcal{S}_{i,i}\geq% \eta]e^{\tau\mathcal{S}_{i,i}}}{\sum_{j\in[b]}\mathds{I}[\mathcal{S}_{i,j}\geq% \eta]e^{\tau\mathcal{S}_{i,j}}}.caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_b ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG blackboard_I [ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_Î· ] italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_b ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_I [ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_Î· ] italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG .

This follows the intuition that, at the fine-tuning stage, the model only needs to get better at distinguishing between records that have high similarity and is already accurate enough to separate relevant from non-relevant items. Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ and Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· are related and are jointly set through hyperparameter tuning.

Modeling details and hyper-parameter Tuning. For both Adaptor and PTFT, we did hyperparameter tuning to determine the learning rate (and use of a scheduler), batch size (although for PTFT it is bottlenecked by GPU memory size), number of training steps, model architecture and initialization (for Adaptor, we tried linear up to 8 layer MLPs) and which layers to train (for PTFT, we tried training the full model or training the last layer), and the choice and parameters of the loss function. We only performed hyper-parameter tuning for BGE-S, and used the resulting hyper-parameters for other models. We note that the choice of initialization is particularly important for Adaptor, and we observed a significant advantage to ensuring that at initialization, Adaptor is an identity function. For a single-layer adaptor, this can be achieved by setting the weight matrix to the identity matrix (also done by Llama IndexÂ (LlamaIndex, 2024c)). For multi-layer adaptors, using ReLU activation, assuming queries are normalized (so that a query input ğ’’â‰¥âˆ’1ğ’’1{\bm{q}}\geq-1bold_italic_q â‰¥ - 1), we achieve this by setting the weights to identity, the bias of first layer to +1, the bias of last layer to -1 and other biases to 0. We are unaware of this initialization being used by existing work for multi-layer adaptors, and we observed benefits to using this initialization over initialization that modify the embeddings at initialization (e.g., setting all biases to 0).

Efficient Implementation. For Adaptor, our implementation is based on Llama IndexÂ LlamaIndex (2024b) and for PTFT based on Sentence Transformers Aarsen (2024), but with additional considerations for initialization (for Adaptor, see above), loss function (see above) and efficiency. We observed that validation passes (for model checkpointing) often take longer than training passes (because the number of data records is often more than the number of training queries in our datasets), we used hyperparameter tuning to set the validation frequency to as low as possible without affecting final accuracy. For Adptor, when applying Adaptor only to queries (so that data records donâ€™t get embedded), we also used a vector index (Faiss libraryÂ Douze etÂ al. (2024)) but did not observe any speed-ups (perhaps due to the already parallelizable nature of answering batched queries, and that we only do top-1 lookup during validation). For PTFT, a single validation pass, which requires re-embedding the entire dataset, can take more than an hour on our large datasets (Fever, NQ, TriviaQA, HotpotQA). To reduce the computational cost, for each validation query, we selected its top-10 answers based on the pre-trained model and only included those (in addition to ground-truth training and validation answers) data records in the dataset for validation. This provided more than 10x speed-up for validation on large datasets, and we observed similar final accuracy (intuitively, this removes data records from validation that, unless the pre-trained model significantly changes, are unlikely to impact validation accuracy). Finally, we use early stopping if validation accuracy drops by more than 5% compared with the maximum it had achieved.

E.2 Other Per Dataset Results

TablesÂ 9-12 present the per dataset results for the embedding models GTE-L, TE3-L, CLIP-B and CLIP-L. The tables (in addition to TableÂ 6) present the detailed results from which TablesÂ 3-5 are generated.

E.3 Training and Validation Accuracy During Training

To better understand the differences and failure modes of the approaches, Fig.Â 2 shows the validation and training accuracy for Adaptor, PTFT and \name-IM, where T and V respectively signify training and validation sets.

Fig.Â 2 (a) and (b) show two failure modes for Adaptor, overfitting, and underfitting. Specifically, Fig.Â 2 (a) shows \name provides much better validation accuracy compared with Adaptors at the same training accuracy, suggesting that Adaptor simply overfits to the training set instead of learning generalizable patterns. Fig.Â 2 (b) shows the other end of the spectrum, where Adaptor fails to fit the training set at all (while \name both fits the training set and improves validation accuracy). We observed this behavior on large data and query sets. We also observed (but not shown here) that increasing the number of parameters, e.g., by introducing additional layers, did not improve accuracy, suggesting that perhaps using adaptors is a wrong modeling choice. Fig.Â 2 (c) shows the only dataset where Adaptor performs well, where it both fits the training set and improves validation accuracy.

PTFT, on the other hand, has a much smaller generalization gap compared with Adaptor. However, both validation and training accuracy increase at a much slower pace, and eventually plateau. Especially for NQ, we observe that the model underfits the training set. We hypothesized that one reason could be due to the loss function used, where indeed Table.Â 6 shows our attempt at modifying the loss function does help improve accuracy on NQ, but not consistently across datasets (and worsens the accuracy on other datasets).

E.4 Normalization Ablation Study

We compare \name-N, with \name-IN (as described in Sec.Â C) with two other potential variants to understand the impact of normalization. \name-M+N is a variant that first performs \name-M and then normalizes embeddings post-hoc. \name-IM+R is a variation of \name-IM with L2 regularization added to the loss to penalize embeddings with large norms. TableÂ 13 shows the results for this experiment, showing that normalizing embeddings after optimization, i.e., \name-M+N performs worse than when normalization is considered as part of optimization, which is the case for both \name-IN and \name-N. \name-IM+R performs worse than all methods, showing an advantage for enforcing a normalization constraint over L2 regularization. Meanwhile, \name-IN and \name-N perform similarly (see Sec.Â C for a discussion between the two).

E.5 Iterative vs. Closed-Form \name variants

We present results comparing \name-M and \name-IM. We use \name-IM-(Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, tğ‘¡titalic_t) to refer to \name-IM with learning rate Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± run for tğ‘¡titalic_t iteration (although we use model checkpointing based on validation accuracy, so the presented accuracy can be for a model trained with fewer iterations than tğ‘¡titalic_t). Overall, the results show that \name-M saves time while providing the best accuracy, while some \name-IM variants are as accurate while being less efficient. Nonetheless, \name-IM variants are simple to implement and more flexible (e.g., in terms of validation accuracy metric to use), and thus may be preferred in some applications.
